dialogues.speaker: EXT. A GRAVE MARKER SUMMER DAY
dialogues.text: It's a plywood cross leaning aslant. Written on the cross black paint which has faded: SMUCKY  HE WAS OBEDIENT. The are faded. They are also straggling and ill-formed--the w child. MAIN TITLES BEGIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A child's printing again, this time on a chunk of warped

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think all these shots are LAP DISSOLVES. All is silence the crickets and the wind stirring the grass. Around the themselves, the grass has been clipped short, and by some there are flowers in cheap vases. Crisco cans, Skippy pea butter jars, etc. These two markers: IN MEMORY OF MARTA OUR PET RABIT DYED 1965 (on a wide flat board) and GEN PATTON (OUR! GOOD! DO 1958 (another board).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't read all of them; some are too faded (or the  "gravestones" themselves too degenerated), but we can see this woodland clearing's a rather eerie -- and well-popul animal graveyard. We can see: POLYNESIA, 1953 and HANNAH THE BEST DOG THAT LIVED. HANNAH'S tombstone is part of an old Chevrolet hoo painstakingly hammered flat. MAIN TITLES CONTINUE.

dialogues.speaker: THE PET SEMATARY
dialogues.text: From here we can see most of the clearing, which is surro forest pines. We can see that the graves--maybe 80 in all arranged in rough concentric circles. On the far side of clearing is the end of a path which spills into this grav clearing. The end of the path is flanked by wooden poles hold up a crude arch. We can see no writing on this side words on the arch face those arriving along the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAIN TITLES CONCLUDE. Written on the arch in faded black the work of some long-gone child: PET SEMATARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWN to look through the arch. From this angle we are loo across to a deadfall--a tangle of weather-whitened old de branches at the back of the graveyard. It's maybe twenty- from side to side and about nine feet high. At either end thick tangles of underbrush that look impassible. AS MAIN TITLES CONCLUDE, THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN on th deadfall. And as it does, we realize that there is a horr snarling face in those branches. Is this an accident? Coi Our imagination? Perhaps the audience will wonder. THE CA HOLDS ON IT and then we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK. And a white title card: MOVING DAY.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A HOUSE IN THE COUNTRY EVENING
dialogues.text: SOUND of crickets: ree-ree-ree-ree... To the left of this house: a big empty field. Behind it: woods. Before it: a wide two-lane road. The house is a pleasant two-story New England dwelling wi shed/garage attached. In front of it is a sign which read REALTORS 292 HAMMOND STREET, BANGOR. A big SOLD strip, li bumper sticker, has been plastered across it diagonally. GROWING SOUND: the rumble of a truck. A big, big truck. I between the CAMERA and the house -- a tanker truck with a body and the word ORINCO written on the side in blue lett short-stack is blowing quantities of dark brown smoke. Be comes a Ford wagon, which slows, signals, and turns into driveway of the house we've been looking at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As LOUIS CREED brings it to a stop we get a good look at license plate (Illinois) and a bumper sticker (HAVE YOU H

dialogues.speaker: YOUR M.D. TODAY
dialogues.text: The ENGINE SOUND stops. For a moment or two we hear only ree-ree-ree of crickets. Then: ELLIE CREED (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this our new house, daddy? LOUIS CREED (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two front doors and one back door open. LOUIS CREED, gets out from the driver's side. RACHEL CREED, his wife, from the passenger side. From the rear door comes ELLIE C girl of 6. They are staring, fascinated, at the house. They come together, the three of them, by the front of th still staring at the house. LOUIS is clearly nervous. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...what do you think? RACHEL begins to smile. She turns to LOUIS and hugs him. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gorgeous! ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I really gonna have my own room? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yaay! She looks toward the side lawn and sees a tire on a rope down from the bough of a tree. ELLIE (to RACHEL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a swing? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but the rope might be-- ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yaay! She goes running toward it. RACHEL gives LOUIS a tired sm LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her go. It's cool. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, the house is beautiful. They kiss--gently at first, then more passionately. As he her more tightly against him, a baby--GAGE--begins to cry car. LOUIS and RACHEL break the clinch. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Master of Disaster awakes. This SOUND is joined by the unhappy yowling of a pent-up LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Buckaroo Banzai. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on--let's parole 'em. They walk to the car, RACHEL going to one of the back sea LOUIS to the rear of the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAGE is sitting in his car seat, not exactly crying but c yelling to be let out. The seat, dash, and floorboards ar littered with roadmaps, soda cans, Big Mac boxes, and sim crud. These folks have driven all the way from Chicago to this station wagon, and the wagon looks it. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decided to wake up and see what home looks like, huh? She begins to unbuckle the straps and harnesses. GAGE is wearing a t-shirt and a diaper. He's fifteen months old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the doorgate and lifts out a cat carrier. We see tomcat inside--mostly what we're aware of are shining gre ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy! Mommy! I see a path! LOUIS, cat carrier still in hand, turns toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got it penduluming back and forth in long wide arcs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the field, and a clearly marked and mown path lead its flank and into the dark woods. THE CAMERA DIPS AND PENDULUMS as ELLIE swings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL (irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so high, Ellie! You don't know how strong that rope is. She puts GAGE down. He totters a bit on his little legs a stands there, looking at his sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bark has rubbed off the branch--it looks like a bone through decayed flesh. The rope is old, discolored. And i fraying away as we look at it. Soon ELLIE, like Humpty Du going to have a great fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's set the cat-carrier down and is straightening up. ELLIE (raptuous voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheee! LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie, you heard your m--- His eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wh-- SOUND: A heavy twang! as the rope breaks. The tire swing- ELLIE still inside it--goes crashing to the grass. ELLIE and begins to cry--a little hurt and a lot surprised. LOUIS and RACHEL run to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie! Are you all right?        Honey? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE'S parents reach the tangle of tire, rope, and six-y girl. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurrts! It hurrrrts! LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone who can scream that loud isn't ready for intensive care just yet-- looks like she just skinned her knee. Nevertheless, he begins to rapidly disentangle his daught the tire. RACHEL helps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's standing in the driveway by the front of the car, ut forgotten in the heat of the moment. His diaper is saggin bit; the boy needs a change. He stares toward the scene of the accident for a bit, the interest. CAMERA FOLLOWS as he walks down the side of the wagon, little bare feet slapping on the asphalt. He stops moment at the back, looking at the cat-carrier, which LOU got around to opening. CHURCH is staring hopefully out th mesh. GAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi-Durch! CHURCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waow! GAGE bends down and tries to open the cat-carrier's door. Either he can't solve the latch or his fingers don't have strength. Anyway, he stops trying after a moment. SOUND: Growing thunder of an approaching truck - a big on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big tanker truck--silver body, ORINCO written on the si blue letters--blasts by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windlash if the passing truck blows GAGE'S hair back forehead. We should be scared here--not by the truck, but GAGE'S lack of fear. He's smiling, happy. GAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Druck! He starts down the driveway toward the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE has been disentangled from the swing. She's sitting wreckage at the end of the driveway, weeping hysterically from tiredness as from pain, I think) as LOUIS and RACHEL her scraped knee. The wound doesn't look too serious. LOUIS (to RACHEL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you get the first aid kit? ELLIE (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the stingy stuff! I don't want the stingy stuff, daddy! RACHEL suddenly looks around toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage's gone! LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, the road! They get up together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A truck is coming. A great big one.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRUCK, CU
dialogues.text: The grille looks like a tombstone that's learned how to s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a step into the road...and then big, gnarled han him. GAGE looks rather surprised at this, but not worried--thi used to being picked up and treated humanely. To GAGE str are as interesting as...well, as interesting as Orinco tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fellow who has picked GAGE up is a man of about eight blue jeans, a faded Bruce Springsteen t-shirt. Over this a faded khaki vest with bright silver buttons. His face i wrinkled and kindly. JUD CRANDALL (to GAGE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't, my friend--not in that road. But he softens this with a grin. GAGE grins back at him. GAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drucks! JUD (low)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit, Sherlock. JUD carries him up the driveway to the station wagon. Her joined by LOUIS and RACHEL, out of breath and really scar brings up the rear. She's still sniffling. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage! JUD (hands him to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was headed for the road, looked like. I corralled him for you, missus. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you so much. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--thanks. I'm Louis Creed. He sticks out his hand and JUD shakes it. LOUIS takes it crushing JayCees grip, or anything like that--the old guy if he might have arthritis. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jud Crandall. I live just across the road. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Rachel. Thanks again for saving the wandering minstrel boy, here. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No harm, no foul. But you want to watch out for that road. Those damn trucks go back and forth all day and most of the night. He leans over toward ELLIE. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who might you be, little Miss? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Ellen Creed and I live at 642 Alden Lane, Dearborn, Michigan. (Pause) At least, I used to. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you live on Route 9 in Ludlow, and your dad's gonna be the new doctor up to the college, I hear, and I think you're going to be just as happy as a clam here, Ellen Creed. ELLIE (to LOUIS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are clams really happy? They all laugh--even GAGE. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Crandall--I've got to change this kid. It's nice to meet you. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same here. Come over and visit when you get the chance. As RACHEL, carrying GAGE, moves away: ELLIE (worries)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, do I really have to have the stingy stuff? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-I guess not. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yayyy! She goes belting off. JUD (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess your daughter there ain't going to die after all. LOUIS (also amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess not. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: House has stood empty for too long. It's damn good to see people in it again. SOUND: A truck engine, gearing down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It blinks and comes lumbering into the Creed's driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey--they actually found the place! JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Movin' in's mighty thirsty work. I usually sit out on my porch of an evening and pour a couple of beers over m'dinner. Come on over and join me, if you want. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I---- RACHEL (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, what's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAGE has been changed, and RACHEL is following him as he the nearest edges of the new homestead. They are fairly c the wreckage of the tire swing, and here is the head of t ELLIE has already glimpsed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross to the van. The FIRST and SECOND MOVERS are ju climbing out of the van. FIRST MOVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Mr. Creed? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Just a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's holding GAGE on her hip now, and both of them are l that strange (and oddly enticing) path which disappears i deepening twilight. LOUIS and JUD join them. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The movers-- RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--I know. This path, Louis? Where does it go? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have the slightest idea. When I saw the house, this field was under four feet of snow. RACHEL (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet Mr. Crandall knows! JUD nods. He smiles, too, but underneath the smile we sen he is serious. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, ayuh! I know. It's a good story, and a good walk, too. I'll take you up there sometime, and tell you the story, too-- after you get settled in. He smiles at them and they smile back--it is a look of  understanding and real liking, in spite of the age differ between the CREEDS and JUD.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CREED HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: SOUND: Crickets. Ree--ree--ree-ree...  There's one light upstairs, one downstairs. Perhaps we se path, glimmering away into the field? Either by virtue of mown, or by virtue of some gentle optical trick? Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: There's a light on in the kitchen, but it just casts a di here. The room has a fireplace and a lovely wooden floor. going to be nice, but now it's just a big bare box with m cartons stacked all over the place. LOUIS is drinking a can of Pepsi, and he looks pretty dam tired--anyone who's ever moved house and can remember the night in the new place will understand. He finishes the last of the Pepsi and surveys the living sits on one of the bigger boxes, takes cigarettes from hi and lights one. He drops the spent match in the empty can taps into the can during the scene. SOUND: Feet coming down the stairs. The door on the far s the room opens and RACHEL comes in, wearing a nightgown. RACHEL (crossing to LOUIS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids are asleep, doc. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. He hugs her. She hugs him back warmly--for a moment they two good people in all the big darkness of their new hous RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not really going over to have a beer with that old guy, are you? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got a million questions about the area, and--- RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ---and you'll end up doing a free consultation on his arthritis or urinary problems and--- LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see his shirt? RACHEL (giggles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Bruce Springsteen. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really do have a million questions about the area...but the thing I'm really curious about is how come this octogenarian Yankee is decorating the slumped remains of his pecs with the Boss. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE PATH OF THE CRANDALL HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Pervasive SOUND of the crickets as LOUIS comes rather hes up the crazy-paved path from the road's edge. JUD (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you, doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the SQUEAK of a rocker; we see the dim red fitful JUD'S Pall Mall. We see by its glow that he is wearing Wa earphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Walkman is in his lap. He switches it off and puts th headphones casually around his neck, like a kid. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come on up and have a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS comes on up. JUD has got a pail of ice beside his c some cans of beer in it. He opens one and hands it to LOU JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a glass? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you. LOUIS drinks half the can at a draught. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, that's fine. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't it just? The man who invented beer, Louis, that man was having a prime day for himself. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you listening to? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allman Brothers. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Eat A Peach album. God, they were good before drugs and bad luck caught up with them. Listen to this, Louis. He passes the headphones over. LOUIS puts them on. JUD pr Walkman's PLAY button. SOUND: Ramblin' Man blasts us out of our seats. LOUIS winces and rakes the spidery earphones off his head JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Wait. He turns it down. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try that. LOUIS puts the earphones back on and listens for a few mo It's the instrumental break. Gregg and Duane Allman dueli Fenders. LOUIS takes the earphones off. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like rock and roll. No...I guess that's too mild. I love it. Since my ears started to die out on me, it's the only music I can really hear. And since my wife died...I dunno, some- times a little rock and roll fills up night. Not always, but sometimes. (Pause) One more time--welcome to Ludlow. Hope your time here will be a happy one. LOUIS (great sincerity)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Crandall. He drinks again--they both do. There's a moment of compan silence here, broken by the SOUND of a big truck. They lo toward:

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. THE ROAD, (THROUGH THE PORCH SCREEN)
dialogues.text: One of those big tanker trucks goes rumbling by--now ther little amber running lights on top of it. It's going fast sweeps by in a blast of air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (wincing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus! JUD (lights a cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one mean road, all right--you remember that path your wife commented on? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one that goes into the woods--sure. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That road--and those Orinco trucks-- are the two main reasons it's there. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's at the end of it? JUD (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day--after you get settled in a bit. Meantime, doc--- Here JUD raises his glass in a toast. JUD (continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to your bones. LOUIS clinks his glass against JUD'S. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yours. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROUTE 9 NIGHT
dialogues.text: LOUIS crosses from the CRANDALL side to his own, and the FOLLOWS as he walks slowly up the driveway and past the w pauses for a moment, looking thoughtfully--hopefully--at house. Then something--the CRY of an OWL, perhaps--draws attention the other way...toward the path. He walks to its head and stands looking out at it--it gli a wide cut swath that's a bit ghostly in the dark. A SHAPE suddenly lurches out of the high grass at him, an recoils with a startled, muffled cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat, sure; who--or what--else? We see his big green e the dark as he cries his strange feline hello: Waow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Church! God, you scared the life out of me! CHURCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waow! LOUIS bends and picks up the cat. As he does, that truck comes again and he looks toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Orinco tanker drones by, fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (to the cat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know one thing that will keep you home, good buddy. He starts toward the house. BLACK. And in that blackness, we see a second title card: SPEAK.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A KITCHEN BLACKBOARD, CU DAY
dialogues.text: Written on it is: MONDAY 1.) CHURCH SPAYED 10 A.M. QUENTI JOLANDER, D.V.M. And below, in even bigger letters: 2.) E

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DAY OF SCHOOL
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PANS LEFT, showing us the kitchen. There are s few cardboard cartons around, but the place is getting in We look out the window and see the CREEDS, led by JUD CRA climbing the path toward the woods. LOUIS has got GAGE in Gerrypak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are also at the edge of the woods. JUD stops and let catch up. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look behind you. They turn around, and their faces express their wonder. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God! RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is indeed beautiful. The CREED house is in the f.g., R just behind it (with one of the ever-present Orinco truck along), but behind that is the great sweep of the Penobsc valley, dozing under a fall sky of clear blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You folks ready to go on? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where are we going, Mr. Crandall? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see soon enough, hon. They go into the woods, still following the path.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST DAY
dialogues.text: These are old woods indeed--huge trunks with dusty sunlig shafting through them. It looks as though man has never m mark here. THE CAMERA PANS SLOWLY DOWN to them, on the path. Here it carpeted with pine needles, but it is just as clearly mar JUD stops. LOUIS looks glad of the rest; he's sweating an are wide dark patches under his arms where the Gerrypak's are. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who owns the woods up ahead? Paper companies? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. The Micmac Indians. What's up ahead is all that's left of their tribal lands. ELLIE (giggling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Micmac, Ricmac, Kickmac, Sickmac. JUD (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayuh, it's a funny word, ain't it? You tired of totin' that yowwen yet, doc? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet...how much further is it? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, you'll be okay. Less than a mile. He starts off again, fresh as a daisy. ELLIE scampers aft LOUIS rolls his eyes at his wife and RACHEL rolls hers ba they press on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD (stopping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the place, honey. ELLIE is of course second. Se tries to read the words on but can't. She whips around to look at her mother. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it say, mommy? A strange expression has come over RACHEL'S face--she doe this. Not a bit. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says Pet Cemetery, hon. It's misspelled, but...that's what it says. She runs for the arch. RACHEL starts; looks more uneasy t RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's almost under the arch. She looks back, questioning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL (a bit lame)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes racing into the Pet Sematary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD lights a cigarette with a wooden match, using his thu JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you it was a bad road, Louis--it's killed a lot of pets and made a lot of kids unhappy. But at least something good come of it. This place. ELLIE (excited voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom! Dad! Y'oughtta see it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She surveys the rude markers with puzzled delight, then r toward the center, pausing to investigate some of the mar she goes. We clearly see the symmetrical pattern of rings

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are walking slowly toward that rude archway. LOUIS i extremely interested in all this, but it's becoming clear clearer that RACHEL is troubled. They stop and look in. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you call it a good thing? A graveyard for pets killed in the road! Built and maintained by broken- hearted children! JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, but Missus Creed! It ain't quite that way, deah! LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's rather extraordinary. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extraordinarily morbid, maybe. She's growing more and more upset. JUD looks at her curio JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...they have to learn about death somehow, now don't they, Missus Creed? The little ones? RACHEL (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...well, because-- ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy! Daddy! Look at me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has begun to climb it, and this looks like an extreme dangerous proposition. ELLIE, however, is having the time life. A branch breaks under one of her feet and she switc nimbly to the next one up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, honey! You don't want to go climbing on that! Come on down! He hurries in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks back at JUD. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Mr. Crandall--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The branch she's on breaks with a dry CRRRACK. Her foot d suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She totters backward, pinwheeling her arms, and JUD catch she falls. Not much of a catch because she wasn't too far LOUIS joins JUD and ELLIE. GAGE jounces along on his back LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a death-wish, Ellen? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I thought it was safe-- JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best never to go climbing on old blowdowns like this, Ellie--sometimes they bite. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bite? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayuh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her discomfort makes one thing very clear--she doesn't wa come in. RACHEL (calls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she all right, Louis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (calls back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine! Come and see!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll sit this one out, doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to look around, daddy-- may I? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a little while. JUD looks toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL has retreated a bit. She sits on the pine needle c the path, opens her purse, and draws out cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD looks at LOUIS as if to say "What's all this about?" looks away. ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Daddy! Look! A goldfishie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs from one tombstone to the next, cheerful as mayb kid could be in such a place. She looks at BIFFER'S tombs SMUCKY'S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are walking slowly toward her. LOUIS is looking at t tombstones. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hardly read these. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayuh--they get older as you go toward the middle. (Points) Pete LaVasseur's dog is buried there... (points) the Stoppard boys' racing pigeon that Missus Cowley's cat  got...and I think that's the cat  himself right there, although it's been so many years I can't tell for sure. (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missy Ellen! Come over here just a  minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs amid the tombstones--they have worked their way the center and there are quite a few of them--and joins t adults. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you're quite a reader for such a little girl. Can you read that? He points again, and Ellen goes over for a look-see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a small slate marker slanted to one side. ELLEN rea words laboriously, tracing them with her finger. ELLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Spot a good fellow we love you boy." (Pause) "Owned by Judson...Judson..." Gee, I can't read the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last name's Crandall, little missy. LOUIS looks at him sharply as ELLIE rejoins them. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where I buried my dog Spot when he died of old age in 19 and 14. Dug it good and deep. By the time I finished, I had blisters all over my hands and a hell of a crick in my back. Soil's stony up here. ELLIE looks awed. LOUIS looks a little awed, too. JUD sweeps a hand around, indicating the whole sematary, still looking at ELLEN. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what this place is, Ellie? Oh, I know you know it's a boneyard, but a bone ain't nothing and even a whole pile of 'em don't amount to much. Do you know what a graveyard really is? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I guess not. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a place where the dead speak, Missy. He sees her startled, uneasy expression and laughs. He ru hair reassuringly. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--not right out loud. Their stones speak...or their markers. Even if the  marker ain't nothing but a tin can someone wrote on with a Magic Marker, it speaks. Ain't that so, Louis? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it is so, Ellie. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you can't read what's written on there anymore? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it still says some animal got laid down here after, don't it? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes-- LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that someone cared enough about that animal to mark the spot. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To remember. JUD (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. To remember. This ain't a scary place, Ellie. It's a place of rest and speaking. Can you remember that? ELLIE (a little awed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. They start to walk slowly back toward the arch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's clear she's impatient and out-of-sorts with the whol RACHEL (calls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, can we go? I'm tired!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy! This is a place where dead animals talk! Mr. Crandall said so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But RACHEL is not amused. She doesn't like any of this. RACHEL (soft)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife is not crazy about cemeteries of any kind. As you may have noticed. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither. But I believe in knowing your enemy. LOUIS looks at him, startled, then decides this is a joke laughs. JUD smiles, a trifle thinly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men rejoin RACHEL and ELLIE. LOUIS (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we take too long? RACHEL (curt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if supper's burned, I'm not the one going out for pizza. They move away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The face we saw at the beginning of the movie wasn't ther the visitors were there...but it's sure there now, leerin

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE KITCHEN TRASH CAN NIGHT
dialogues.text: There are two greasy boxes poking out with NAPOLI PIZZA s them. Guess dinner was burned. THE CAMERA PULLS BACK and we se LOUIS sitting at the kitc table. The table is covered with newspapers. On it, LOUIS putting together a complicated model boat, using glue and tweezers. He's wearing glasses. ELLIE comes in, wearing a nightgown. She watches him for LOUIS (not looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, babe. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, that Pet Sematary is there because of the road, isn't it? LOUIS looks around at her, surprised. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I think. I heard Missy Dandridge tell Mom when Church was fixed he wouldn't cross the road so much. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's always better to take precautions--but I'm sure Church will be all right, honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL is coming along with some dirty dishes. She hears and stops, listening, her face troubled and afraid. ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No he won't! Not in the end! He won't be all right in the end no matter how you fix 'im!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellis has started to cry. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the end he's gonna croak, isn't he? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovey...Church might be still alive when you're in a high school...and that's a very long time. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't seem long to me. It seems short. I think the whole thing about pets dying s-s-sucks! Poor kid's bawling her eyes out now. LOUIS folds her into and she hugs him tightly, wanting his comfort. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it was up to me I'd let Church live to be a hundred...but I don't make up the rules. ELLIE (muffled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well who does? God, I suppose. But he's not God's cat! He's my cat! Let God get His own, if He wants one! Not mine! Not mine! Not-- She breaks down completely, sobbing, and LOUIS rocks her forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is crying silently.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ELLIE'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: She is a dimly perceived hump in the darkness. An oblong light falls on her, illuminating her more clearly. She's with her teddy encircled by one arm and her thumb corked mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL looks at her daughter with infinite love and then closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOUIS'S AND RACHEL'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: LOUIS is in his pajamas, propped up on pillows on his sid bed. There a number of medical books scattered around him making notes from one as RACHEL comes in. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's finally asleep. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a little over-excited, that's all. Poor kid. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was that place. That creepy cemetery up in the woods. Whatever disease the kids in this town have got, I don't want Ellie to catch it. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Rachel, what's got into you? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I didn't hear her tonight, crying as if her heart would break? Here she is thinking Church is going to die. It should be clear to us by now that, despite her words, much more upset than ELLIE was. LOUIS slowly puts his not aside and caps his pen. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel...someday Church is going to  die. RACHEL (whirls on him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is hardly the point! Church is not going to die today, or tomorrow-- Never mind. I can see you don't have the slightest idea what I'm talking about. She stalks to the bathroom, which adjoins. LOUIS follows. in and slams the door. He goes for the knob. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel--! SOUND: CLICK OF THE LOCK. LOUIS stares at the door, bewildered and upset.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROUTE 9 NIGHT
dialogues.text: Here comes a big Orinco truck, droning along, headlights

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headlights of the truck illuminate the room and we se and RACHEL asleep, each as far over to his/her own side a can get, with a big empty space in the middle. Lights and TRUCK SOUNDS slowly fade.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GAGE MORNING
dialogues.text: Cheerful little clots of scrambled eggs are scattered all across the tray of his high-chair--it looks a little like the Pacific islands done by a guy who only had a yellow c Now he scoops up a handful and throws them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splat! Eggs on the serving plate of toast. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yee-uck! Gross!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL is at the sink, doing dishes (we see the blackboar its message near her). LOUIS comes in, wearing a sport-coat and slacks, ready fo first day on the job...and ELLIE is in a pretty first day school dress. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't help it, babe. Emily Post is going to be beyond him for a few years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is the cat-carrier with CHURCH inside it. He waows u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE gets down and goes across to the cat-carrier. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want him to get his nuts cut, daddy! What if he dies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS looks shocked and amused by ELLIE'S colorful choice words. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God! Where'd you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missy Dandridge. And she says it's a operation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS tries to kiss RACHEL'S mouth. She turns her head sl he gets her cheek instead. She's still mad. LOUIS'S amuse dies. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, Church will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if he dies and has to go to the Pet Sematary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a look as if to say: "There! Now do you und what you did?" RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. Church is not going to die. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to what Mr. Crandall says, the road's a lot more dangerous than the operation. Church will be just the same. Well--almost the same--and we won't have to worry about him getting turned into catburgers by one of those damn Orinco trucks. At this RACHEL tightens up still more in that funny way-- actually angered by LOUIS'S reference to catburgers--but anger we sense she is deeply shocked, as a prudish woman shocked by a dirty joke. For RACHEL, that's just what dea RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough of that kind of talk! LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just said-- RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you just said. Ellie, clear your place. ELLIE goes slowly back to the table. ELLIE (sets the plate down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm scared. What if school here isn't like in Chicago! I'm scared and I want to go h-h-home! ELLIE bursts into loud tears and puts her hands over her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA FOLLOWS as they go to the table to comfort ELL RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be fine, Ellie. Now you can be excused. Go and wash your face. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Church will be fine. ELLIE (anxious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you promise, Daddy? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, honey...you know that... RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Give the little girl her promise. LOUIS (reluctantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Church will be fine. I promise. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yayyyy! She runs off, cheered up. And RACHEL is cheered up, too. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Louis. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're welcome. Only if some- thing should go wrong while he's under the gas--it's a one-in-a-thousand shot, but it happens--you explain to her. He gets up and leaves the table. She looks after him, stu a little frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAGE (conversationally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, Durch! He picks up a large glob of scrambled eggs from his tray throws it in the direction of the cat-carrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHURCH is close to the mesh, looking out. Scrambled eggs mesh, driving him back, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CREED HOUSE MORNING
dialogues.text: The school bus pulls up, red lights flashing. ELLIE runs across the lawn, with her lunch-box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a great day! LOUIS grabs GAGE'S hand and makes him wave it. GAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye-bye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE climbs aboard. The red flashers go out and the bus away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CREED DRIVEWAY MORNING
dialogues.text: The station wagon is parked there. LOUIS comes out with a briefcase in one hand and the cat-carrier in the other. H the wagon's doorgate. A small car turns into the CREED driveway and parks besid A rather sour-looking middle-aged woman gets out and cros front of her car. Her color is bad. This is MISSY DANDRID looks at the cat-carrier. MISSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna get his-- LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --nuts cut, yes. Thank you, Missy, for introducing that colorful phrase into my daughter's vocabulary. MISSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention it. She opens the passenger side door of her car and we see a pile of folded sheets. She reaches for them, then winces presses her hands against her midriff for a moment, as if attack of indigestion. LOUIS (sees this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that belly-ache of yours? MISSY (gets the sheets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No better and no worse. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to see a doctor about it. MISSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll pass. They always do. She starts toward the house with the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SIDE YARD MORNING
dialogues.text: RACHEL hurries past MISSY, who turns to look and then goe the house. LOUIS has just put the cat-carrier into the ba wagon and closed the doorgate as RACHEL reaches him. RACHEL (anxious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still friends, doc? LOUIS appears to consider this seriously for a moment...a he smiles and hugs her. They kiss. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God. I was a little worried there. Have a great first day at school, doc. No broken bones. LOUIS (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so much as a sprain.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VICTOR PASCOW AND FRIENDS MORNING
dialogues.text: PASCOW is in a blanket that is being carried by three boy girl. They are all yelling at each other not to joggle hi drop him. A small knot of horrified college kids moves wi bearers. PASCOW'S head is upside down to the CAMERA, which retreat of the advancing students. Fixed eyes stare. Half of his been shattered inward. Before the catastrophe he was a hu of about twenty. He's dressed in a U of M muscle shirt an jogging shorts. THE CAMERA PULLS JERKILY TO ONE SIDE, allowing the bearer mount the steps of a brick building. The infirmary. The l break to either side. The infirmary doors open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the head nurse, a tough old babe of about fifty. CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Jesus. (turns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve! Steve! Dr. Creed! Dr. Creed, we've got a mess here! Stat! The bearers sweep past her and inside, leaving a red smea blood across the midriff of MARCY CHARLTON'S uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA will show us all we need to see, but its movem seem almost random; this is like being in the hotel kitch Sirhan shot Bobby. As the students bring in PASCOW, LOUIS comes running, fol STEVE MASTERTON, his P.A. Standing to one side are two st nurses in candystriper uniforms. They're boggled and horr LOUIS kneels. THE CAMERA RUSHES FORWARD, shoving between  onlookers. LOUIS looks at the wound. There's shattered bo pulsing brain tissue beneath. There's a scream; the girl who was carrying one corner of blanket is having hysterics. GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic! Vic! Oh Christ! Vic! LOUIS (to CHARLTON)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get her out. Get them all out. CHARLTON puts her arms around the girl. GIRL (struggling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No! He can't die! He can't die! THE CAMERA MOVES BACK DOWN as LOUIS takes an opthalmascop STEVE and shines it in PASCOW'S bulging, fixed eyes. CHARLTON is just pushing the last of them gawkers and bea the door. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, get the ambulance over here right now. He's got to go to EMMC. STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance is at Sonny's Sunoco downtown, getting-- LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --a new muffler, oh shit-- PASCOW makes a weird gargling noise. Blood suddenly spurt his mouth. He begins to seizure. One of the candystripers shrieks. THE CAMERA JERKS UP TO student nurses. One turns and throws up on the wall. CHARLTON rushes over. CANDYSTRIPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't look at it...I can't stand it... CHARLTON (slaps her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you by God can. Go get the hard stretcher! As they start away, one helping the other down the hall, CHARLTON starts over to where PASCOW lies dying on his bl THE CAMERA DROPS TO LOUIS AND STEVE. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me hold him. They hold PASCOW'S spasming body. STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't matter if we did have the ambulance. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't matter if we had the SST. PASCOW begins to quiet. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going. Steve, go call the motor- pool. Marcy, roll out the crash wagon. CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't-- LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it won't! But let's for God's sake do it by the rules! She leaves. LOUIS is alone with PASCOW. CHARLTON has draw drapes, so the doctor and the dying man have complete if privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wasn't even supposed to be a sprain today, my friend--that's what I told her. PASCOW'S fixed eyes suddenly roll and his left hand bear- LOUIS'S right wrist. The dying man pulls him slowly but  relentlessly down, until their faces are only inches apar PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Pet Sematary... LOUIS recoils, breaking the grip of the hand...but he can snap the grip of those bright dying eyes. Blood leaks fro PASCOW'S mouth. LOUIS (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-What did you say...? PASCOW struggles hard to speak again. At first he can onl PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the real cemetery... (Long pause) The soil of a man's heart is stonier, Louis...a man grows what he can...and tends it. LOUIS leans forward again, terrified, yet needing to know LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know my name? PASCOW (gurgling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come...to you. LOUIS grabs PASCOW'S bloody shoulder. LOUIS (low but urgent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, how do you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, they're sending a--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW begins to spasm again. LOUIS (snaps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me! PASCOW spews more blood as STEVE kneels beside LOUIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLTON is pushing along your basic MEDCU goodie-cart, c with emergency life-saving gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW'S spasms are weakening. LOUIS (to CHARLTON)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. He's going. PASCOW'S hand comes up and paws at LOUIS'S shirt, leaving handprint. Then it falls limply back. PASCOW is dead. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, will you get a sheet to cover him with? STEVE leaves the frame and LOUIS stares fixedly down at t of VICTOR PASCOW. He closes the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A COUNTRY ROAD, LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: It's the leading edge of Maine fall, sunny and wonderful. comes LOUIS'S station wagon. As it reaches THE CAMERA, it to TRACK. RADIO (voice-over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tragedy struck on the first day of the University of Maine's fall semester  when Victor Pascow, a nineteen-year-old sophomore--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He still looks shocked by the tragedy. The dying man's bl handprint is partly visible on LOUIS'S shirt in spite of sport-coat. LOUIS abruptly turns off the radio and swerves over to th the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IT comes to a slueing, shuddering stop, almost going in t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said my name. I heard it. He said my name. He stares blankly through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CREED HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: All lights are off. It's late.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CREED BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: LOUIS and RACHEL are asleep, each on his/her own side of double. THE CAMERA MOVES IN ON LOUIS. SOUND: Loud, hollow BANG. It's very loud--loud enough to dead. LOUIS sits up. Beside him, RACHEL sleeps on. LOUIS'S eyes terror as he stares at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's exquisitely dead. Now pallid as well as smashed up. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, doc. We got places to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in terror...but he is also in a state of near-tranc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, doc--don't make me tell you twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at RACHEL. Although PASCOW has spoken in a fai voice--and the opening door was like a bomb--she's still asleep. LOUIS looks back toward PASCOW...and then gets ou He's naked except for a pair of pajama bottoms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and leaves the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches the bedroom doorway himself and looks back at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL is sleeping as before, and LOUIS himself is also i asleep, although his rest is uneasy...as if he's having a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (relieved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank God. PASCOW (Voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up, doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS enters and crosses toward the door which gives on t shed/garage. This door stands open. LOUIS pauses by it. PASCOW (low)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, doc... LOUIS goes into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station wagon is a dark hulk. LOUIS crosses to it and perplexed. PASCOW looms softly behind him and puts an arm around him turns... and suddenly his face is less than an inch from mutilated face. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, doc. LOUIS (moans)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like this dream. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said you were dreaming? He begins to move toward the garage door. After a moment follows him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE FIELD BEHIND THE HOUSE, LONG NIGHT
dialogues.text: We can see two shapes moving up the path toward the woods and, behind him, LOUIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA HOLDS, THEN PANS DOWN as LOUIS passes under the ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around, obviously afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see why. By starlight this is one scary place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly sees something else, and now his fear is clos terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The face is back in the tumbled branches. It yawns and sn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks toward the deadfall as if hypnotized. PASCOW'S h on his shoulder. LOUIS turns, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He really is a dreadful mangled mess. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the place where the dead speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes his eyes. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to wake up. I want to wake up, that's all. I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door must not be opened. The barrier must not be crossed. Don't go on, doc. No matter how much you feel you have to. There's more power here than you know. He points at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That grinning face--and perhaps now there are other effec well, subtle but there? Dim red light? A misty smoke drif through the tumbled dead branches? The director will know After a moment there is a HUGE GRUNTING ROAR from the woo the deadfall--it sounds like no animal we've ever heard b There is the sound of something huge shifting and snappin like a toothpick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS has crumbled to PASCOW'S feet. His eyes are squeeze shut. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I want to wake up. Leave me  alone. It's not my fault you died; you  were as good as dead when they brought you in-- PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The power of this place is old and always restless. Sometimes the dead do more than speak. Remember, doc. CAMERA BEGINS MOVING SLOWLY IN ON LOUIS. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone! PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember. CAMERA IS TIGHT ON LOUIS. RADIO (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --another beautiful day in Maine! This is Michael O'Hara sayin' that the git-go ain't gonna be that bad. Temps are going all the way up to 70... We got the Ramones for Ludlow...here's "Sheena." As the Ramones start blasting "Sheena Is A Punk Rocker":

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes snap open. He's in his own bedroom. As he sits u CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS OUT so we can see that he's in bed al covers on RACHEL'S side are thrown back. After the initial confusion and fear, LOUIS looks deeply he looks the way I suppose we all look upon waking up and realizing our worst dreams were only dreams after all. RACHEL (calls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You up, doc? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting there. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got eggs down here! LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good d-- He throws the covers back and freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are covered with mud and pine needles. The sheets ar with woods-muck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Utter terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS'S hands enter the shot and dump a bundle of sheets chute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's naked but for a towel around his waist. He's obvious from the shower. He starts down to the bedroom to dress. BLACK. And on it a third title card: CHURCH. Over this the SOUND of a RINGING TELEPHONE. LOUIS (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CREED LIVING ROOM AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: There's a bowling match on TV. LOUIS, dressed in his Satu afternoon grubs (jeans and a Maine sweatshirt), has the p his ear. JUD CRANDALL (phone filter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis? 'Fraid you may have a spot of trouble. LOUIS (frowning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jud? What trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on the phone, looking out his window. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you tell me Rachel took the kids back to Chicago for a few days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Ellie's birthday, yes. I didn't go because her old man thinks I'm a shit and the feeling is heartily re- ciprocated...they'll be back tomorrow night. Jud, what's this about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's a dead cat over here on the edge of my lawn, Louis. I think it might be your daughter's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Church? Oh. Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking across from the CREED lawn. LOUIS waits for those trucks to go blasting by and then crosses. It's col windy. Downed autumn leaves fly. LOUIS and JUD stand over a small furry body like mourners JUD (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lying on its belly and doesn't look much damaged. Ha LOUIS'S--come into the frame. He puts one hand under the head and lifts it so the open eyes, now a dull green, sta THE CAMERA. There's some blood on its ruff. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Church. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. At least it don't look like he suffered. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie will, though. She'll suffer plenty. From his jacket pocket he takes a green plastic garbage b hands it to JUD. JUD holds the bag's mouth open on the gr while LOUIS kind of shoves the body in. During this: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loved that cat pretty well, didn't she? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. LOUIS twists the bag shut and puts one of those plastic t it. Then he holds it up. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagged cat. What a mess. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to bury him in the Pet Sematary? LOUIS (a little bitter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that's what it's there for, huh? During all of this JUD has grown peculiarly intense. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going to tell Ellie? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like you told me about a promise you made--

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CREED KITCHEN MORNING
dialogues.text: GAGE is in his high chair. ELLIE, in her first-day-of-sch dress, is in her place. LOUIS is sitting at his own place hypnotized, at the middle of the table, where there is a serving dish. On the dish is scrambled eggs, strips of ba CHURCH'S corpse--staring eyes, bloody ruff and all. RACHEL (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Give the little girl her promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a mistake. But Rachel... she doesn't like to talk about death, or even think of it. Her younger sister died of spinal meningitis when Rachel was eight. Rachel was there when it happened. Alone. I guess you could say it made a complex. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cat's just as dead, Louis. LOUIS (snaps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's a big help! (Pause) I'm sorry, Jud. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to apologize. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe when they call I'll just tell Ellie I haven't seen the damn cat around. You know? JUD (after a long pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there's a better way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS and JUD cross the road from the CRANDALL side. LOUI carrying the plastic bag in one hand and a flashlight in other. JUD has a pick and shovel in one hand and a flashl his own in the other. Evening shadows have grown long. It's maybe an hour until JUD and LOUIS stop near the replaced tire-swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD has a Walkman clipped to the belt of his pants and ea slung around his neck. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jud, this is crazy. It's going to be almost dark before we get back. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be dark before we even get where we're going, Louis. But we can do it...and we're going to. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But-- JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does she love the cat? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but-- JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then come on. He puts the earphones on, effectively forestalling furthe argument, and pushes the PLAY button on the Walkman. We c Marshall Crenshaw singing "Crystal Girl." JUD starts away moment, LOUIS follows.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE PET SEMATARY AND THE BACK OF THE ARCH LATE EVE
dialogues.text: The SOUND of crickets...ree-ree-ree... The SOUND of footfalls. Faintly, the SOUND of Huey Lewis and the News, singing "W For A Living." It's now almost twilight. JUD and LOUIS enter the Pet Sematary. LOUIS is looking ar curiously. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, folks, here we are, in Louis Creed Dreamland. JUD snaps off the Walkman and puts the earphones around h again. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What say, Louis? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. (Pause) Do we plant him on the outer circle or start a new one? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're still not where we're going. He walks past LOUIS and toward the deadfall. LOUIS follow LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place we're going is on the other side of that. He points at the deadfall. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't climb over that. We'll break our necks! JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We won't. I have climbed it a time or two before, and I know all the places to step. Just follow me...move easy...don't look down...and don't stop. If you stop, you'll crash through for sure. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not climbing that. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the cat. I'll take care of it myself. He holds out his hand and LOUIS sees the old man means ex he says. After a moment he says: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. JUD starts up one side of the deadfall, and in spite of i snarled tangles, he mounts as easily as a man climbing a stairs. After a few second, LOUIS follows. LOUIS (low)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God my Blue Cross is paid up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First JUD'S pass THE CAMERA, then LOUIS'S, partly obscure swinging cat-bag. Their feet unerringly find the right br and just as unerringly miss holes which look like ankle-b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's grinning, exhilarated. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, this is amazing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are beads of sweat on the old man's face. He looks stern and a little scared. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't stop and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dead branch snaps under one of them like a gunshot and plunges down maybe six inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lurches to the edge of balance, then regains it. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't look down. Right. He continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD reaches the top and starts down the far side. LOUIS r the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (amazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dying glow of twilight, this should be a mystic, a inspiring shot. There's no more scrub underbrush and junk and juniper-bracken here; ancient firs rise almost like S The sunset light shafts among them. This is a real forest old forest. And winding upward among the trees along that carpeted floor, clearly marked by large white stones, the goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's stopped on top of the deadfall, still surveying all frank amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD (turns to look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Louis--don't stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right! I'm f--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the branches snaps. LOUIS'S foot plunges. His cuff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking up at a fairly steep angle as LOUIS stagger balance. He steps with his other foot, misses, and goes f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does a half-somersault in the air and hits the deadfal back, the green garbage bag flying out of his hand. His f also goes. Branches crack. White dust puffs out from unde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS thumps to the ground nearby. JUD kneels beside him. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis! You all right? LOUIS sits up groggily. His pants are torn. His sweatshir torn. His ankle is bleeding. LOUIS (dazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I guess I just lost my happy  thoughts for a second there. LOUIS gets slowly up and retrieves the bag, which is rath shredded now--and we can see catfur through some of the r LOUIS (continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have stopped...and it does bite. He whaps the flashlight against his palm a time or two an light comes on. Satisfied, he shuts it off. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you shouldn't have stopped. But you got away with it. Important thing is are you sure you're all right? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (Pause) Where are we going, Jud? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see before long. Let's go. He starts off up the path. After a moment LOUIS follows, the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, there should be a sense of awe and mystery as they tolling up the path into the twilight, dwarfed by those a firs. SOUND OF CRICKETS, LOW at first, then UP TO LOUD: Ree-ree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of undergrowth here, and creeping ground-mist, too. OF CRICKETS is now only a part of the soundtrack: BUZZ OF THUMP OF FROGS. Swamp-sounds. LOUIS looks frankly doubtful. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This next bit's like the deadfall, Louis-- you got to walk steady and easy. Just follow me and don't look down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mysterious...awesome...scary. Dead trees poke out of the twisted hands. There's scummy water standing around tusso covered with long grass, most of it dead. There's a lot o underbrush. All of this fades away into a grim, obscuring fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Micmacs used to call it Little God Swamp. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there quicksand? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayuh. LOUIS (nervous; joking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there ghosts? JUD looks at him expressionlessly. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayuh. JUD starts off, stepping to the first tussock. After a mo LOUIS follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face is set, strange. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of funny things down this way, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD (still walking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air's heavier...more electrical... something. You might see St. Elmo's Fire...what the sailors call 'foo-lights.' It makes funny shapes, but it's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE looks up and his eyes widen as he sees:

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GOD SWAMP, LOUIS'S POV
dialogues.text: A faintly glowing, ethereal shape hangs in the branches o the dead trees. It looks a bit like a corpse. In fact, I looks quite a bit like PASCOW'S corpse. As we watch it fades...fades...is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's somewhere between being mystified and puzzled and be scared. Now a weakly glowing fireball rolls slowly across surface of the standing water toward him...and then just into the thick mist. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't stop, Louis. You don't ever want to stop down here in Little God. (Pause) And you don't ever want to look behind you, whatever you hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see them moving through the mist like wraiths, JUD wit digging tools, LOUIS with his light and his Hefty-Bag cof whole swamp is glowing dimly.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE FAR SIDE OF LITTLE GOD SWAMP NIGHT
dialogues.text: In the extreme f.g. we can see firm ground sloping up. Ah thick white mist. And here comes JUD and LOUIS slogging t and out of it. Both of them are wet from the knees down. into the woods on the far side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the book this is described as being almost a cliff, bu hill rising out of the woods would serve just as well. We steps cut into the side, and two figures--LOUIS and JUD-- up them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD'S panting and out of breath; LOUIS is, if anything, i shape. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost there, Louis. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep saying that. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time I mean it. He tops the last step and stands on a rocky level under t the wind blowing his hair off his deeply lined brow. A fe later LOUIS joins him and stares with undisguised wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The top of this hill or bluff is rocky and bare, but ther number of rocky piles. But for every pile of rocks we can there are ten littered heaps, as if the neat piles had be apart. There's a shape to all of this, and it is the shap Pet Sematary: concentric circles. SOUND: The wind, blowing ceaselessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (awed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this place? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was their burying ground, Louis. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose burying ground? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Micmac Indians. I brought you here to bury Ellen's cat. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? For God's sake, why? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had my reasons, Louis. We'll talk later. All right? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so...but... JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to rest a bit before you start? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm okay. Will I really be able to dig him a grave? The soil looks thin. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soil's thin, all right. But you'll manage. He hands him the pick and shovel. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to sit over yonder and have a smoke. I'd help you, but you've got to do it yourself. Each buries his own. That's how it was done then. JUD walks away, leaving LOUIS with the digging tools in o and the flashlight in the other. After a minute, LOUIS wa into the burying ground.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LOOKING DOWN INTO A SHALLOW HOLE NIGHT
dialogues.text: SOUND: The wind. It blows ceaselessly up here. The hole's about two and a half feet deep. Stubby rocks p from the sides. The pick comes down, hits a rock at the b and flashes fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops the pick and sticks his hurt hands in his armpit him we see a low pile of rocks and earth. JUD (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should be deep enough. He joins LOUIS. He's got a lot of rocks in his arms. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so? He notices the rocks. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are those for? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your cairn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those tumbled piles of rock are very obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't look like they last long. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about that. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jud, why am I doing all this? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's right. He walks off again. LOUIS looks after him for a moment, then kneels down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens it and looks in at CHURCH'S stiffening corpse. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pax vobiscum, Church old buddy. You were a hell of a god cat. I doubt if you were worth all this aggravation, but you were a hell of a good cat. He tumbles the bag containing the body into the grave, an begins pushing the stony soil over it with the spade.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CAIRN, CU NIGHT
dialogues.text: LOUIS'S hands come into the frame and add a final two or stones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at it for a moment and stands up. JUD is right t JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine. You did real good. LOUIS looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CREED HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: There's a light on in the kitchen, but that's all. There' at first, and then the PHONE STARTS RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LOUIS'S FIELD NIGHT
dialogues.text: LOUIS and JUD are coming down the path with their tools a lights. They are both clearly fagged out. SOUND, FAINT: The telephone. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit! Rachel! He drops the tools and sprints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS runs into the side yard. SOUND of the phone is loud

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs to the door and inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands there, eyes inscrutable.
