dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stops. A beat later LOUIS enters the room. He picks it although he already knows it's too late. He listens to th of the dial tone and then drops it back into the cradle,  disgusted. He starts to dial a number from memory. JUD (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you talk to 'em, not one word about what we done tonight. 'S'far's you know, the cat's still fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment he lowers it into the cradle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll understand. In the meantime, keep your peace. What we did, Louis, was a secret thing. Women are supposed to be the ones who are good at keeping secrets, but any woman who knows anything at all would tell you she's never seen into a man's heart. The soil of a man's heart is stonier, Louis--like the soil up there in the old Micmac burying ground. A man grows what he can...and tends it. During this, he's come across the room to LOUIS and dropp hand on LOUIS'S shoulder. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But-- JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No buts! Accept what's done, Louis. What we done was right. Another time it might not be, but tonight it was... at least I hope to Christ it was. Now you make your call...but not a word about tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUNDS: Boops and beeps of a touch-tone telephone. Ringin DORY GOLDMAN (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goldman residence. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Dory...it's Louis-- During this, another SOUND has been growing: an approachi As JUD gains his side of the road, he looks back, and we on his face--no matter what he said to LOUIS, he's sorry tonight's piece of work. A moment later a highballing Orinco truck cuts between TH and JUD.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOUIS, IN THE LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: He's on the phone, smiling and happy. RACHEL (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to talk to the birthday girl? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd be real fine. ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...daddy? LOUIS (sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday to you/Happy birthday to you/Happy birthday, dear Ellie/Happy birthday to you! ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was awful, daddy. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know...how are things out  there in Chicagoland? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine...except when Mom was airing Gage's diaper rash, he walked away and got into Grampa's study and pooped in Grampa's favorite chair. LOUIS (grinning broadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way to go, Gage! ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said that's too bad. What did you get for presents from Gramma and Grampa? ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of stuff! I got two dresses...and a Chatty Cathy doll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's dressed for bed, in fuzzy pink pajamas. Her Chatty crooked in one arm. In her lap is a Garfield transistor r ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and a Garfield radio! How's Church, dad? Does he miss me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smile fades off his face. It's replaced with a look o combined guilt and unhappiness. He's looking at his hands are still dark with the dirt from CHURCH'S grave. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I guess he's just fine, Ellie. I haven't seen him this evening, but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL, holding GAGE, sits on the arm of ELLIE'S chair. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, make sure you put him down cellar before you go to bed so he can't run out in the road and get greased. And kiss him goodnight for me. LOUIS (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yuck! Kiss your own cat! ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to talk to Gage? Before he can answer, she puts the phone in GAGE'S hand. RACHEL watch, amused, as GAGE gobbles into it. Perhaps RA encourages him to say a few words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the telephone comes the sound of GAGE talking and ch LOUIS is not listening. His eyes--and his mind--are far a

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CREED HOUSE MORNING
dialogues.text: LOUIS is raking leaves on the side lawn, near the tree wi tire swing. After a moment or two of this he props the ra against the tree and starts toward the garage. He goes in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dim in here. LOUIS is crossing to the door which com to the kitchen. As he passes the station wagon, he hears HISS. He turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on top of the car, but at this point we probably don notice; THE CAMERA is so close that CHURCH looks like he' right down our throats. He's hissing angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He recoils and stumbles backward with a cry. He hits a to on the wall and a lot of them fall down with a LOUD JANGL NOISE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps down, frightened by the noise, and the CAMERA TR he goes flying out the garage door into the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets slowly to his feet again. He's getting over his f we can see he's totally freaked out by what gave him that He goes to the garage door and looks out. LOUIS (calls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Church?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grass and fallen leaves. No sign of CHURCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's spooning cat-food into a dish. He goes to the door-- should be a total of three doors in the kitchen: one to t room, one to the shed/garage, and one which leads directl outside. LOUIS uses this latter door now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the dish of food down and sits beside it. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Food, Church...food! SOUND: Miaow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHURCH comes slinking out of the bushes and comes slowly THE CAMERA. He stops, looking mistrustful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Church! Chow down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the stoop and begins eating the food. LOUIS (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ. I don't believe this. He picks CHURCH up. CHURCH miaows again--he wants the foo LOUIS (wincing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you stink, Church. CHURCH is looking at the food, trying to get out of LOUIS LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a second. He tilts the cat's head back so he can get a look at CHUR neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some sort of mark here--a clear remnant        of line of white fur, or perhaps a dark red scar where no fu grows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS sees something else as he lets the cat's neck go. H something out of CHURCH'S whiskers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shred of green plastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chewed his way out. Jesus Baldheaded Christ, he ch-- CHURCH suddenly claws at his face. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! He claps his hand to his face. CHURCH leaps for the food. slowly takes his hand away. There are claw marks on his c welling blood. He looks at the cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garden is a plot of about half an acre. JUD comes tru slowly along a row, pushing a wheelbarrow. There are seve pumpkins in it. JUD is wearing old khaki gardening pants Ramones sweatshirt. He's wearing his headphones and we ca the Romantics doing "What I Like About You." JUD is singi and bopping a little--as much as his arthritis will allow can dig it. He sees a real big pumpkin, stops, and bends over to get He takes out his pocket-knife and slits the pumpkin-vine. the pumpkin in his arms and stands up. He turns...and LOU right there (kind of a cheap jump, but always fun), looki totally stunned. JUD, startled, drops the pumpkin. LOUIS reaches out and s phones off JUD'S ears. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS is sitting at the kitchen table. JUD is at the frid comes back with a couple of long-necked bottles of beer a them. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I most generally don't start before noon, but this looks like an exception. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did we do, Jud? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, saved a little girl from being unhappy...that's all. Drink up, Louis! LOUIS drinks about half the beer. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to tell myself I buried him alive. You know--Edgar Allan Poe meets Felix the Cat. But... JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't wash? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm a doctor. I know death when I see it, and Church was dead. He smells horrible and he uses his claws, but he's alive...and I feel like I'm going crazy. It was that place, wasn't it? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayuh. It was the rag-man told me about the place--Stanley Bouchard. Us kids just called him Stanny B. He was half Micmac himself. LOUIS drains his beer. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have another one? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it wouldn't hurt. He gets up and goes to the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Micmacs used to bury their dead up there long before the whites came. He returns to the table with the beer. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They buried their dead and for a long time their dead stayed buried. Then something happened. Half the tribe died in a season. The rest moved on. They said a Wendigo had soured the ground. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendigo? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spirit of the north country. Not a good spirit. Wendigos are great liars and tricksters, according to the stories.  And if one touches you... JUD pauses, perhaps a flustered, and gathers his thoughts JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it really was a Wendigo-- I ain't the one to say it wasn't-- or maybe it was just some disease. Whatever the reason, those that were left moved on. But they left that place...the way it is now. JUD shrugs, and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JUD AS A BOY, CU/SEPIA TONE DAY
dialogues.text: The time here is about 1910. JUD is wearing short pants. crying, not in any big-deal histrionic way, but as if he keep doing it for a long time. I mean he looks really sad JUD (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved my dog a lot, Louis. When Spot died, I thought I was gonna die. JUD is sitting on the front stoop. It's the same house JU in now, but the porch hasn't been added yet, and the road rather than tar. Along this road comes a horse-drawn wagon--STANNY B.'S wa wagon's full of junk, rags, bottles...stuff to sell and s Strung across the top are bells, and we can hear their CH SOUND...but faint, like bells heard in a dream. STANNY B. is old and drunk. Dust spumes up behind the wag draws up to the CRANDALL house and stops. He gets down, a falls, takes a bottle out of his back pocket, drinks, and approaches JUD. We can see him speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and this old Indian rag-man-- JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanny B. did for me what I did for you last night, Louis. Only I wasn't alone when Spot came back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CRANDALL BACK YARD/SEPIA TONE DAY
dialogues.text: JUD'S MOTHER is back to THE CAMERA, hanging sheets on the The sheets billow. And suddenly, pushing out from behind quite near her, is a small mongrel dog. SPOT. He's covere graveyard dirt. His eyes are red and rolling. He splashes sheets with the muck of his passage. JUD (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother was with me. She sees who it is--what it is--and backs away, screaming horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd got caught in bobwire that infected. You could still see the marks on him. And so we can, around his neck and along the side of his These marks are the counterpart of the marks we've alread CHURCH. SOUND of JUD'S MOM SCREAMING. Like the bells, these are s heard in a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOY JUD comes running out, dressed in a night-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's cringing against the fence at the rear of the yard. stands in front of her, swaying from side to side, as if JUD'S MOM (dim; far)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your dog, Jud! He stinks of the ground you buried him in! Come here and get your dog! She is in utter terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrified...ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD'S MOM (terror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did your mother take it, Jud? How did she take it when your dog came back from the dead? JUD'S face is a complication. He's lying to LOUIS, certai is he also lying to himself? Yes, I think so. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she was a little upset at first, and that's why I thought you ought to hold your peace when you talked to your people last night...you did, didn't you, Louis? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, then, things should be fine. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little upset is all she was? Because I'll tell you, Jud, my brains feel a little like a nuclear reactor on the edge of a meltdown. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got used to the idea. Spot lived another four years. He died peacefully in the night that second time, and I buried him in the Pet Sematary...where his bones still lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see them crossing. LOUIS (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still haven't told me why you did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man doesn't always know why he does things, Louis. I think I did it because your daughter ain't ready for her favorite pet to die. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie's a little scared of death. And the main reason Ellie's that way is because your wife is a lot scared of death. Now you just go ahead and tell me I'm wrong. But LOUIS'S reaction tells him he's not wrong--in fact, J hit the nail right on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS'S hands come into the frame and turn the spigots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to undress, still looking troubled. We should n that the door behind him is firmly shut. The bathroom has windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hot water is steaming. LOUIS'S hands enter the frame off the faucets. SOUND of LOUIS climbing in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big sigh and an expression of exquisite pleasure. He re the hot water. After a few moments he puts a wet washclot his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Give the little girl her promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAGE is in his high chair. ELLIE is at her place, crying. RACHEL'S place sits VICTOR PASCOW, bloody and wrecked. LO in his place. On the platter of bacon and scrambled eggs CHURCH'S mangled body. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door must not be opened. The barrier must not be crossed. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The washrag is slipping, but it still covers his face. LOUIS (mutters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I'm a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In attendance: PASCOW, LOUIS, ELLIE, GAGE in his high cha in the middle of the table, clotted with dirt and blood, staring, neck a gory mess of infected wounds, is SPOT. He dotted with clots of scrambled egg and bits of bacon. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes the dead do more than speak. Remember, doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL (with great force)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Promise me. Promise me. Promise me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The washcloth has slipped enough so we can see his eyes a closed--he's dozing. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To LOUIS, ELLIE, PASCOW, GAGE, and the corpse of SPOT ent his eyes shocked and staring. JUD (to LOUIS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do it for all the best reasons, but that ain't why. You do it because it gets hold of you...you do it because you have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The washrag has worked its way down to his mouth by now. is deepening; he's started to snore a little. SOUND: A splash. Something has been dropped into the bath LOUIS opens his eyes. Looks puzzled. Looks down. Eyes wid shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very large and very mangled dead rat floats in the bath actually brushing against LOUIS'S chest. Blood has begun the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns his head, preparatory to leaping out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its mouth yawns open. It hisses, showing bloodstained tee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS leaps from the tub. Grabs a towel and begins to rub frantically. He's grossed out. The cat tries to arch agai and he hits it. CHURCH falls to the floor, hissing. LOUIS looks at the closed door. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell did you get in? He may not know that, but he knows how it's going to get opens the door to the upstairs hall. If CHURCH doesn't go LOUIS helps it with his foot. Then he looks down at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring at the rat. Over this: THE SOUND OF JET ENGINES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its landing gear unfolds preparatory to touching down at International Airport.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A DEPLANING AREA DAY
dialogues.text: Lots of people making their way up the jetway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's looking anxiously for his people. In one hand he's g dozen roses. His face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes LOUIS'S family. ELLIE is a little ahead. RACHE pushing GAGE in his stroller. ELLIE sees LOUIS and lights ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy! She runs for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE comes belting up to LOUIS, weaving among the deplan a slalom skier. She leaps into his arms. LOUIS swings her cheerfully. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, sugar! She smacks him noisily. He smacks her back just as noisil ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, is Church all right? LOUIS'S face changes. All at once he's watchful. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...I guess so. He was sleeping on the front porch when I left. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause I had a bad dream about him. I dreamed he got hit by a car and you and Mr. Crandall buried him in the Pet Sematary. LOUIS (trying to smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a silly dream, wasn't it? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he really all right? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you promised. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. RACHEL reaches them. She's pretty tired. Hair hanging in good travelling clothes now looking a bit wrinkled and a stale. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to take your son, doc? LOUIS does. GAGE is ecstatic. LOUIS kisses RACHEL deeply.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CREED KITCHEN, NIGHT
dialogues.text: CHURCH at the door, waiting to be let out. ELLIE does the CHURCH oils out into the shed/garage. ELLIE closes the do looks distressed. She crosses the kitchen again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CREED LIVING ROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: RACHEL, in a flannel nightgown, is watching TV. LOUIS is medical tome and making notes. GAGE, zipped into a warm b suit, is sacking on the couch. ELLIE (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can cats have shampoos? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--you have to take them to someone who grooms animals, though. I think it's pretty expensive. ELLIE (still upset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. I'll save up my allowance and pay for it. Church smells bad. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've noticed it, too. I'll cough up the money, Ellen. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate that smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks both grim and sad--a man discovering that what y for you own, and what you own always comes home to you. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--I hate it, too. BLACK. And on it, a fourth title card: MISSY DANDRIDGE. SOUND: A pen scratching over paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single sheet of lined paper is spotlighted by the glow desk-lamp. On it, MISSY'S right hand is just finishing: " Intestinal Cancer. Cannot face this Pain. Sorry." The hand puts the pen down. It tears the paper in two, le just the half with the message.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE DANDRIDGE CELLAR, NIGHT
dialogues.text: A light comes on and we see a hangman's noose strung over It dangles above a kitchen table which has been relegated cellar duty. SOUND: Descending footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of MISSY climbing onto the table. Her face enters the frame. She looks very sick. She puts into the noose and rakes it tight at the hyoid bone.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DANDRIDGE HOUSE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: One light on...a cellar light. SOUND: Ree-ree-ree...then... SOUND: Kick! THUMP! SOUND: Ree-ree-ree...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs limply, hands dangling at her sides, above the which now lies upon its side. We can see the note clearly pinned it to the bodice of her housedress. SOUND: Car engines starting up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. IN FRONT OF THE GRACE METHODIST CHURCH DAY
dialogues.text: People are coming out and getting into their cars and tur the headlights, even though it is only mid-morning. In the immediate f.g. is a hearse. Four pallbearers are l coffin into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all turning on their lights! Daddy, why are they all turning on their lights in the middle of the day? JUD, dressed in a rusty old black suit and a black tie, c and stands with them. He looks haggard and old. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do it to honor the dead, Ellen. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right, dad? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. To honor the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More cars start up; more lights come on; the back doors o hearse swing closed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LUDLOW CEMETARY DAY
dialogues.text: [NOTE: In the book LOUIS finds it difficult to enter at n because of a high iron fence. Here we should see there's problem; there's only a low stone wall between the gravey the public road.] The mourners are of course gathered around the grave of M DANDRIDGE. The coffin rests above it on runners. MINISTER (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May the Lord bless you and keep you; may the Lord make his face to shine upon you, and comfort you, and lift you up, and give you peace. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the mourners begin to break up, these three start back LOUIS'S car. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel not feeling well? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...a touch of the flu... ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in bed. She was throwing up. Ever since Mrs. Rogers called and said Missy-- LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough, Ellen. They've reached the CREED station wagon. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the mouths of babes, Louis. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This babe has said enough. He opens the front passenger door. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hop in, Ellie. She does, and LOUIS closes the door. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Missy. God, I was sorry to hear. I remember when she was no older'n Ellen there, walking down to the store with her Raggedy Anne doll draggin' behind her in the dust. I don't know why God takes someone like her, who should have a bunch of years still in front of them, and lets an old shit like me just go on and on. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father used to have a saying, Jud-- "God sees the truth, but waits." JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayuh...how is your cat, Louis? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Ellie's cat. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. He's your cat now. JUD opens one of the back doors as LOUIS goes around to t driver's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD has tilted over in one corner and is snoring. His Wal 'phones are on and we can hear the tinny sounds of Billy little old man's drool trickles down from one corner of h SOUND: ELLEN< crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears are spilling freely down ELLIE'S face. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie? What's wrong? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more chocolate chip cookies. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missy made the best chocolate chip cookies in the world--even Mom said so. Now there won't be any more because she's gonna be dead forever! She cries harder. LOUIS reaches out and strokes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE STATION WAGON, DAY
dialogues.text: Moving up the country road toward home through blazing fa foliage.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TV SCREEN, CU NIGHT
dialogues.text: On it is a scene from "Night of the Living Dead." NEWSCASTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bizarre as it may seem, it now seems almost beyond doubt: the dead are returning to eat the living. ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CREED LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: There's a VCR on top of the TV; LOUIS has been watching " Now he quickly uses the remote control to shut down the T She's dressed for bed, and comes toward him slowly. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up, sugar? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, do you think Missy Dandridge went to heaven? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's putting away the last of the supper things. She hea and moves toward the living room door to listen. She does at all well. Her eyes are red from crying and her face is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gotten up into his lap. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At school Michael McDowell said she was gonna fry in hell. Michael McDowell says all sewersides fry in hell. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think Michael McDowell is so full of shit he probably squeaks when he walks, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles a little at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't you dare say that. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't...is Missy in heaven, do you think? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, honey. Different people believe all sorts of different things happen to us when we die. Some believe in heaven or hell. Some think we're born again as little children-- ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, carnation. Like in that movie you rented, Audrey Rose. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's actually reincarnation, but you get the idea. And some people think we just wink out...like a candle flame when the wind blows hard. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe that? LOUIS looks toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHURCH is sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we go on. I'm not sure what happens after we die, but yeah-- I have faith in that. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe in it. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, faith's a little more than just believing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what faith is--it's the evidence of the heart; the assurance of things not seen. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here we are, sitting in my chair. Do you think my chair will be here tomorrow? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you have faith in that. But we don't know it will be; after all, some crazed chair-burglar might break in while we're away and steal it, right? ELLIE'S giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's smiling, too...but tears are running down her cheek

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we plan on that chair. We believe in that chair. And I plan on going on somehow as Louis Creed, after I die. I believe I will. ELLIE (awed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have faith in that. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am. Just like I have faith that it is now time for Ellen Creed to get ready for bed. So buzz. He gets her off his lap. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not tired! LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you're not. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do I have to go to bed? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because your mother and I need the rest, sugar. Now buzz. She heads toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS is in bed, reading. RACHEL, wearing a robe over her nightgown, comes in. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you tonight. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you did. I know you don't approve of the subject being raised-- RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true. The subject scares me. Because of Zelda. LOUIS puts his book down and looks at her thoughtfully. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister, I know. RACHEL sits down on the end of the bed. She's clasping he nervously together. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you're so good with her, Louis--so straight with her--that you make me ashamed of myself. LOUIS sits up and scoots down the bed to her. He tries to arm around her. She rejects it--but gently. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I couldn't go with you to Missy's funeral. And that I blew up when we went to that silly animal graveyard. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's forgotten. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not by me, it isn't. I know how badly I acted, how unfair I was. It's just that I..you know. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I guess I do. He makes a place for her beside him and hugs her. They li silently together for awhile, taking comfort from each ot RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to try to do better. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK. And on it, a fifth title card: GAGE. SOUND: An idling truck motor.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE GRILLE OF A TRUCK DAY
dialogues.text: It looks monstrous...as high as a mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an Orinco tanker. The driver, a young man in khaki f and a baseball cap, climbs up into the cab. He slams the jams the truck into gear. IRWIN GOLDMAN (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew something like this would happen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE ORINCO SHIPPING YARD DAY
dialogues.text: The truck comes rolling slowly toward the main gate...sto driver can look both ways...and then pulls slowly out ont 9. IRWIN (voice continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her when you were first married. 'You'll have all the grief you can stand, and more,' I said.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A FUNERAL CHAPEL, WITH IRWIN GOLDMAN AND LOUIS DAY
dialogues.text: There are others here, but they are in the b.g., and conc on the scene the old man is making. He's RACHEL'S dad. LO sitting in the aisle seat of a pew-like bench. He looks t shattered--they both do, actually. He's staring at the ol if he cannot in the least comprehend what he's saying. IRWIN (continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now look at this! He gestures toward:

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE FRONT OF THE FUNERAL CHAPEL DAY
dialogues.text: Here, half-buried in floral tributes, is a child-sized co GAGE'S.

dialogues.speaker: INT. IRWIN AND LOUIS DAY
dialogues.text: IRWIN (weeping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run over in the road like a...a chipmunk!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROUTE 9, W/TRUCK DAY
dialogues.text: Getting up to speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a hand holding it--LOUIS'S. The kite begins to mo THE CAMERA TRACKS IT. It flaps and flutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs with the kite beneath a gorgeous fall sky in whic clouds move like airy ocean liners. ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, daddy!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A PICNIC TABLE DAY
dialogues.text: The remains of a picnic lunch are spread here. Looks like ate well. In attendance: RACHEL, ELLIE, GAGE, and JUD CRA GAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, dayee! They all laugh--JUD ruffles the kid's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's paying out string--and the kite is going up. LOUIS (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Rachel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRWIN looks toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are by the sign-in book. Both are dressed in black. haggard. But RACHEL looks more than haggard; she looks da insane with grief and horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRWIN (leaning forward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her mother! Where she should be! As for you, I hope you rot in hell! In hell, do you hear me? We should; by now he's screaming his head off.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CAB OF THE ORINCO TRUCK DAY
dialogues.text: The driver is whistling. A transistor radio hangs from th view mirror on a strap. He turns it on. The Ramones. "She Hey-ho, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unrolling before us at a good clip--too good, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stamping the pedal closer to the metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belting toward THE CAMERA. SOUND of the GROWLING ENGINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS has clearly gotten it up okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's holding the string, looking up at the sky. Now he lo at the picnic table. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Gage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAGE gets down and runs toward his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belting along fast. SOUND of the Ramones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAGE runs to his dad, chubby legs working. He reaches him LOUIS transfers thee ball of string to GAGE'S hands. GAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dat? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: String! You're flying it, Gage--you got the hammer, my man! GAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage fline it? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet your boots. Look-- LOUIS puts his hands over GAGE'S hands and pulls them dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It dips in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? GAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage fline it!! LOUIS (tenderly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet your ass, little hero. He kisses his son. They look up at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dipping and drifting in that gorgeous fall sky. IRWIN GOLDMAN (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you while he was playing in the road? Thinking about your stupid medical articles? You stinking shit! You killer of children!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You-- But there is no way he can express his outrage with mere LOUIS sits staring numbly up at him, IRWIN punches him in nose. LOUIS sprawls backward, falling out of the pew onto floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL screams and starts forward. DORY pulls her back. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis! Daddy! Stop it! STOP IT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS is getting up groggily. Hs nose is pouring blood. IRWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like that, you son of a bitch? I should have done it sooner! IRWIN punches him in the stomach. LOUIS "oofs" and double

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHER MOURNERS
dialogues.text: Among them we see STEVE MASTERTON and MARCY CHARLTON. STEVE (getting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS is slowly straightening up. IRWIN is in a sour fren glee. IRWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like that? How do-- LOUIS pushes the old man with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes stumbling and flailing backwards...strikes the co knocks it off its bier. A SCREAM goes up from the mourner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL screams. Her mother struggles to hold her but RACH breaks free and goes running down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: MOURNERS, WITH MARCY AND STEVE
dialogues.text: MARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop them. Right now. STEVE gets up and goes toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's picking himself out of a tangled mess of coffin and  overturned floral tributes. His suit is wet from spilled He's weeping. LOUIS has just reached him, and that stunned look is gone he intends to do the Cool Jerk all over IRWIN GOLDMAN'S p little body. IRWIN strikes a Gentleman Jim Corbett pugili pose. IRWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! I'm ready for ya! I'll take y'apart! As LOUIS wades in, STEVE MASTERTON gets between them...at possible moment. STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! LOUIS swings. STEVE manages to block the punch with his b STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! Jesus, what's wrong with you, Louis? It's your son's funeral, not a boxing match! That gets to LOUIS. He drops his fists. That stunned expr creeps over his face again--that look that says he doesn' the slightest clue as to what's going on or how it could have happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soil of a man's heart is stonier, doc-- LOUIS turns toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW, bloody and ruined in his jogging shorts and muscl has the pew to himself...except for CHURCH, who is sittin lap and PURRING. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man grows what he can...and tends it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sense of horrible awareness comes into his face...and t covers it with his hands and begins to SOB. SOUND, COMING UP: A TRUCK MOTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trucker is singing along with the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's closer to the floorboards than ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are at some distance--far enough to see that the two o have moved quite close to the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see their faces upturned to us--we can hear the AM RATTLING SOUND of the kite itself. THE CAMERA PANS TO THE LEFT--to the road. And we can see truck, fairly close by now, and coming closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD'S lighting a cigarette. His Walkman 'phones are aroun neck. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to fly it! Can I fly it now, mommy! RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a minute, hon. Let Gage finish his turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the last moment of happiness in this man's life-- make it very happy. As he and GAGE stare up at the kite: IRWIN (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Louis. I'm sorry--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fight has gone out of IRWIN and STEVE has backed away cautiously. He's ready to jump back in if one or the othe mad again. But IRWIN is shuffling toward LOUIS, hands out everyone else has gathered in a knot near the front of th Among them is RACHEL and her mother, weeping in each othe IRWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what happened to me. Louis, please-- LOUIS brushes by him with no acknowledgement that IRWIN e exists. He kneels down slowly by the coffin and puts his against it. LOUIS (weeping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Gage--I'm so sorry, little hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a strong gust of wind. The ball of string falls o GAGE'S hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It got away from him! That numb shit! RACHEL (outraged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen Creed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is bouncing and unraveling. More importantly, it is be carried directly toward the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off after the ball of twine. GAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kite fline too fast! SOUND: The oncoming truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slamming toward us--a brutal leviathan on eighteen wheels

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's looking--looking toward his people at the picnic tab LOUIS (shrugs, good-humored)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can you d- TRUCK SOUND CONTINUES.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK SOUND LOUDER.
dialogues.text: Alarm hits JUD'S face. He rises. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let him go in the road, Louis! RACHEL looks; registers terrible alarm. RACHEL (screams)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him, Louis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still scampering after the bouncing ball of kite-twi has now almost reached the road. TRUCK SOUND LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND is loud enough so he's having trouble hearing. LOUIS (cups his ear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL (shrieks)

dialogues.speaker: GET THE BABY
dialogues.text: JUD is running toward the road, although he'll never get in time; only LOUIS has a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrible understanding dawns on his face. He whips around sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid's almost in the road; the ball of twine is in it. RISING DRONE OF THE TRUCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAGE (cheerful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geddit-geddit-geddit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAGE reaches the middle of the road as the truck comes ar corner. LOUIS is running across the field, getting close side of the road. RACHEL is clutching ELLIE by the picnic JUD is helplessly trying to wave the truck down as it pas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he reaches the broken white line he grabs the ball of SOUND OF THE ONCOMING TRUCK. GAGE turns his head. GAGE (not afraid)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Druck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly THE DRIVER'S face turns into a Halloween mask of He BLASTS THE AIR-HORN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (shrieks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLARE OF THE AIR-HORN. A shadow falls over his face. Ther audible CLICK! and we FREEZE FRAME. What we have now is a dously winning photograph of a little boy, not quite two, ball of string in his hand...and a shadow lying across hi
