dialogues.text: a.) LOUIS is pushing RACHEL out of a hospital door. RACHE wheelchair and looks radiantly happy (so, for that matter LOUIS). I think we may safely assume that the small blank bundle in RACHEL'S arms is GAGE. b.) LOUIS, bare to the waist, is tubbing a two-month-old baby-tub. He's laughing. The infant looks confused but ca c.) The whole family by the Christmas tree, following an present-opening. ELLIE, about five, has a doll in each ha and RACHEL are in pajamas. GAGE, about five months, is ly drift of wrapping paper. He looks confused but calm. d.) A child's sneaker lying in the road. It's splashed wi e.) GAGE--he's about nine months old in this snap--is pro in the angle of a sofa. There's a big white rabbit in his GAGE looks c. but c. f.) ELLIE and GAGE, bundled up against the Chicago winter is pulling a child's chair-sled. GAGE is propped up in th He's about eleven months old in this snap. He's laughing. g.) The Orinco tanker, overturned on the far side of Rout h.) This one was taken at Gage's first birthday party. He wearing a party-hat and looking at a birthday cake with a candle on it while LOUIS kisses one cheek and RACHEL kiss other. i.) LOUIS, in the road. He's holding GAGE'S jumper, which blood-soaked, and inside out. LOUIS is looking up toward and screaming. j.) Here is a full-face studio portrait of GAGE. He is sm us, heartbreakingly lovely. CAMERA HOLDS ON THIS while: JUD (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sedative finally took hold. She's asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's holding the studio portrait in his hands and looking fixedly. The other photos (the good ones, that is; not th screamers--those, we may assume, exist only in LOUIS'S to memory) are scattered on the table. We only saw a few; th actually hundreds. LOUIS puts the photo down as JUD comes in and crosses to fridge. LOUIS'S nose is badly swelled. He also has a blac JUD gets a couple of beers and comes back toward the tabl JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father-in-law packs a wallop, for an old guy. He and his wife gone back to Chicago? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...squatting out there at the Holiday Inn like a couple of vultures. He really thinks Rachel's going to go back with them. Her and Ellie. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis-- The swing door opens. They look toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks dazed and shocked. There are brown circles unde eyes, but otherwise her complexion is much too white. She wearing fuzzy pj's. She's carrying the picture of her pul on the sled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE (coming to the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go back to my own room. I can't sleep with mommy. She keeps stealing the covers. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got there, Ellie? At first she doesn't want to show him, but JUD is very ki JUD (studying it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why that's real nice...you pullin' him on a sled. Bet he liked that, didn't he? ELLIE nods. She is starting to cry. JUD is also leaking a eyes. ELLIE (crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to pull 'im a lot. LOUIS, looking down at his hands, nods. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to carry this picture, Mr. Crandall, until God lets Gage come back. JUD reacts violently. And LOUIS looks up, dully curious.. hasn't the thought already passed through LOUIS'S mind? Y think it has. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie...God doesn't do things like that. I know you loved y'brother, but-- ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can if He wants to. He can do anything, just like Inspector Gadget on TV. But I have to keep things ready for him, that's what I think. I've got his picture and I'm going to sit in his chair-- LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie-- ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm going to eat his breakfast cereal, too, even though it tastes like boogers. And...and... She bursts into tears. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, take care of your little girl...she needs you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face is stricken.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ELLIE'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: LOUIS comes in with ELLIE in his arms. He puts her gently bed and pulls the covers up. She's already mostly asleep. LOUIS (kisses her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Ellie. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G'night daddy. He starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God could take it back if He wanted to, couldn't He? If He really, really wanted to? Can I have faith in that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands looking at her for a long time, apparently thin about this quite deeply. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--I suppose you can. Good night, Ellie. He steps out, closing the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In some sense comforted--it may be a poison comfort but s doesn't know this--she turns over on her side to go to sl can see the picture of GAGE under her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light here is fairly dim. LOUIS goes down and opens a door. He pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reacts first with surprise, then a species of horrifie disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHURCH is crouched on RACHEL'S sleeping form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS comes in and swats the cat a damned good one. LOUIS (low snarl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off, hairball!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hisses at him through a mouthful of fangs, its eyes bi balls...and then it flees. CAMERA FOLLOWS IT out the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL stirs and mutters thickly, then lies still again.. doped to the gills. LOUIS bends over and kisses her gentl He leaves the room and closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries the door a couple of times to make sure it's fir the latch (his face wears an expression of "How'd he get in the first place?"). Then he walks down the hall to the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat is on one of the risers. LOUIS trips over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment he's pinwheeling madly for balance, on the v falling. He regains his balance as the cat goes shooting the dining room toward the kitchen. LOUIS regains his equilibrium after a bit and continues o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As LOUIS enters through the swing door from the dining ro is just letting CHURCH out the back door. As JUD closes t LOUIS (slightly antagonistic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd be gone by now. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got you a fresh beer out of the fridge, Louis. He indicates the table, where there is indeed a fresh bee LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jud, I buried my son today and I'm very tired. I wonder if we could just-- JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're thinking of things best not thought of, Louis. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking about going to bed. But he begins pouring the beer into a glass. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never asked me if anyone had buried a person up there in the Micmac burying ground-- LOUIS'S hand jerks. Beer goes foaming across the kitchen JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but I think the thought has crossed your mind. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! Look at this mess! JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayuh--it's a mess, all right. As LOUIS goes to get a cloth to wipe up the mess: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the Micmacs thought it was a holy place...and then they thought it was a cursed place. That's why they moved on. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because something called a wendigo soured the ground. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And because the dead walked. LOUIS stops sopping and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, ayuh. It's been done. What you've been thinking of has been done.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A COUNTRY RAILROAD STATION/SEPIA DAY
dialogues.text: The time is the late summer of 1944, although I don't bel need to know that specifically. The sign on the station r LUDLOW. There are a few 40s cars parked near the station- have gas-ration coupons on the windshields. And a hearse. A train is coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see the UNDERTAKER is trying to talk to BILL BATER man in his forties who periodically wipes his brow with a BILL walks away. He doesn't want to talk; he doesn't want He's a grief-stricken, bitter man. JUD (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timmy Baterman was on his way home from the war with his Purple Heart when he got killed in some stupid car accident down in Georgia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door of the mail-car is open. The UNDERTAKER and thre trainmen are unloading TIMMY BATERMAN'S coffin, which is a 48-star flag. BILL BATERMAN stands by, watching baleful they carry his son's final apartment to the back of the h load it in. JUD (v-o continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill was bitter--his son had been in the thick of it two years and then got shot in the leg--a clean flesh-wound. He was supposed to be coming home safe and sound. Instead, he come home in a box after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors close. The hearse pulls away. THE CAMERA PANS T BATERMAN, who stands staring balefully after it and moppi brow. JUD (v-o continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't able to get to the bottom of the truth, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CREED KITCHEN, WITH LOUIS AND JUD NIGHT
dialogues.text: LOUIS is now sitting down, drinking a beer, staring at JU LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bite--what's the bottom of the truth, Jud? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why...that sometimes dead is better. That's all. Sometimes dead is better. LOUIS (bitter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell that to my wife and little girl. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't your wife and little girl that's got me worried, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE LUDLOW CEMETARY/SEPIA DUSK
dialogues.text: We're featuring a fresh grave...that of TIMMY BATERMAN. A showing only parking lights, turns into the graveyard and slowly up to it. It stops, and BILL BATERMAN gets out. HE the grave and then goes to the back of his truck. JUD (voice-over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timmy was buried on July 22nd, as I remember.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BILL BATERMAN AT THE BACK OF HIS TRUCK/SEPIA DUSK
dialogues.text: He reaches in...and brings out a pick and shovel.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARGIE WASHBURN, ON HER PORCH/SEPIA DAY
dialogues.text: She's a middle-aged woman dressed in mid-forties style. S a rug-beater in one hand; the other is up to her eyes to sun. She's staring at something, horrified. JUD (v-o continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was four or five days later when...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A COUNTRY DIRT ROAD, WITH TIMMY BATERMAN/SEPIA DAY
dialogues.text: A young man dressed in jeans and a plaid shirt is shambli road. His eyes are vacant. His shirt is half untucked. Hi sticking up in a wild crow's-nest thatch. There is an ugl healed scars on his neck and one side of his face. I thin his ears may be gone--torn off in the accident. JUD (v-o continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Margie Washburn seen him walking up the road toward Yorkie's Livery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's screaming--we hear her faintly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns toward her and we see a green light like the St. fire in the Little God Swamp glow dimly deep in his eyes. at MARGIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates for a moment or two and then walks up towar door. JUD (v.o.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of people saw Timmy Baterman walking back and forth between the home place and the town line. But  it was Margie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in a hallway in front of a door with LUDLOW SELECTM printed on the frosted glass. After a moment she opens it in. JUD (v.o. continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...who finally got up enough guts to talk to the town fathers about it. She knew it had to be stopped, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGIE and four men are grouped around a desk. She's talk they're listening. THE CAMERA LAZILY PANS the four men--o course, is JUD as a YOUNG MAN. JUD (v.o. continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knew it was an abomination. George Anderson, the town postmaster, was there...and Alan Purinton...Hannibal Benson...and me. I was there.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BATERMAN PLACE/SEPIA SUNSET
dialogues.text: It's a ramshackle old farm which looks remarkably like th of that gentleman farmer Jordy Verrill. An old Ford pulls into the driveway, and the four men get SOUND BLEEDS IN: Most of all the SOUND OF THE CRICKETS. They go to the door, and JUD is wordlessly elected as the honcho. He knocks. No answer. Again. No answer. SOUND: Crazy laughter. BILL BATERMAN (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that, Timmy! The four men look at each other. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. They start around to the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIMMY BATERMAN is staring directly into the setting sun, glowing with green fire. He's laughing like Goofy gone in BILL, scared, is trying to make him stop, to turn away fr sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four men come around the side of the house. They free they see BILL and TIMMY. ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh holy Jesus lookit that. BILL whirls around and sees them. BILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You men get out of here! JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard your boy was killed down Georgia. BILL (agitated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a mistake! HANNIBAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it? BILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see him standing there, don't you? Now get out! Get the Christ off my land! Now TIMMY turns around and comes shambling forward. TIMMY (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ge ow! Ge Cwise off eye an! GEORGE (revolted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus, Jud! He's dead! I can smell him! BILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't dead! Give him a day or two and he'll be fine! Don't you say that! JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, this ain't right--you can see that yourself-- BILL (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIMMY (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead! We love dead! Hate living! Abruptly he reaches up with both hands and scratches down cheeks, goring deep grooves in his flesh. Blood flows slu out. Very weird blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL grabs TIMMY, who's still laughing wildly, and gets h around. TIMMY shambles back to where he was originally st BILL goes with him like a man who has charge over a train baboon. A stupid trained baboon. BILL (over his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to get out of here before I get my shotgun! You boys are trespassing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God help you, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL (snarls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God never helped me. I helped myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring directly into the setting sun and laughing wildly mindlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BATERMAN PLACE--MONTAGE NIGHT
dialogues.text: a.) A car pulls up with its lights off and stops. JUD (v.o.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a fire. b.) We see legs as people get out of the car, and hands h tin cans of gasoline. c.) Hands splash gasoline from the cans along the sides o house.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BATERMAN PORCH NIGHT
dialogues.text: JUD (as a young man) rings the bell--an old-fashioned twi BILL (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there? TIMMY (laughing, screeching voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooo air? Ooo air? JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out, Billy--the place is going up. He walks away. BILL BATERMAN, wearing a strappy tee-shirt out the window. BILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen you! I seen you, Jud Crandall!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BATERMAN PLACE--MONTAGE NIGHT
dialogues.text: a.) A match is struck...and applied to wet boards. Whoosh b.) The other side of the house: The same. c.) In the back yard, JUD lights a torch and heaves it th kitchen windows. Ka-PLOOM! d.) The men draw away toward the front, their faces grim judgmental.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BATERMAN PLACE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Burning. Going up fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Bill's gonna get out, Jud? JUD (stony)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he don't, he don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It bursts open. We see two men struggling at the forefron inferno--correction, one man and an undead monster. TIMMY giggling and screaming, trying to pull his father back in flames. BILL (struggling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No, Timmy! Let me go! TIMME (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love dead! Hate living! He sinks his teeth into his father's arm. BILL screams. A beam falls on TIMMY, lighting him afire. BILL breaks fr runs down the porch steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's burning and laughing. TIMMY

dialogues.speaker: LOVE DEAD
dialogues.text: And into the fire he goes, still shrieking and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE FRONT YARD NIGHT
dialogues.text: BILL BATERMAN is collapsed on the lawn as sparks drift do him, his face hidden against his thighs, weeping. CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN on the four men, who are grouped a of the driveway by the road and staring with awe at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes dead is better, Louis. BLACK. And on it, a sixth title card: THE DEAD WALK. SOUND BLEEDS IN: JET ENGINES.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BANGOR INTERNATIONAL TERMINAL DAY
dialogues.text: A jet plane rises into the sky from behind the building. GATE AGENT'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the final call for United's flight 61 to Chicago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g. we can see IRWIN and DORY GOLDMAN waiting by jetway with ELLIE as the last few passengers board. RACHE confused and grief-stricken. She also looks punchy, doped imagine she's floating on a sea of Valium, and that makes easier to deal with. LOUIS'S battle-scars are fading a li The GATE AGENT is standing by the jetway with a mike in o and a bunch of boarding passes in the other. GATE AGENT (concludes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All passengers should now be aboard. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get going, hon. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Louis, I just don't know about this-- LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you last night--this can be the start of patching things up with your folks. If something good doesn't come of Gage's death, I think I'll go crazy. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, are you sure? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go to Chicago, Gramma Dory. DORY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not, darling? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a bad dream last night. A nightmare. IRWIN (kindly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About Daddy. (Pause) And Gage. DORY and IRWIN exchange a knowing, sad glance over the ch head. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And someone named Paxcow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS guides her to the jetway. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you guys--before you miss the boat. He kisses DORY. IRWIN hugs him. IRWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, I am sorry. What can I say? That I lost my mind? It's the truth, but no good excuse. LOUIS (hugs him back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all lost our minds, Irwin. LOUIS kisses RACHEL. Then he kneels and hugs ELLIE. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be good to your mother, darlin'. She needs you. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with us, daddy. Please come with us! LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be there in three days--four at the most. I've got to get the electricity shut off and square things with your school so the truant officer ain't after you, and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE (crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, daddy! I'm scared!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of what? ELLIE (crying harder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. LOUIS (great emphasis)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's going to be all right, Ellie. Now go on--get aboard. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you swear? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear. The Voice of Authority has spoken. We can tell by ELLIE'S that while things are still not all right, they are a lit better. She joins her mother. The four of them--RACHEL, ELLIE, and THE GOLDMANS--start jetway. ELLIE looks back once, as if begging him to come. then they're gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS'S face changes. Now it is a stony and contemplative Not, when you get right down to it, a very nice face. He turns and strides away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family station wagon is in the f.g. We hear the SOUND ENGINES, and as LOUIS reaches the wagon he turns and watc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind it a United Airlines jet lifts into view and away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face set, he gets into the wagon and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CREEDmobile pulls up across from the Brewer Tru-Value and LOUIS crosses to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On it: A six-cell flashlight, Duracell D-batteries, a pic shovel, and a nylon drop-sheet in cellophane packaging. N CLERK'S hands come into the frame and drop a pair of heav gloves into the pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else for you today? LOUIS (after a look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we got it all. The CLERK starts to ring things up. CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like heavy work. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be. The quality of LOUIS'S reply is somehow unnatural. The CL at him, momentarily unsure and uncertain. Then he starts things up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE is in the window-seat, asleep. RACHEL is holding a but not reading it. Her eyes are red. She's looking into CAMERA DRIFTS TO ELLIE. Her sleep is not easy. Her head t side to side, as if in negation. She becomes steadily mor She's starting to mutter. Suddenly her eyes flare open an screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see the GOLDMANS in the seats behind the CREEDS. T startled. So are other passengers. A stewardess comes run ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paxcow says it's almost too late! RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie...Ellie...what... ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paxcow says it's almost too late! We have to go back! Paxcow says it's almost too late!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LUDLOW CEMETARY DAY
dialogues.text: The CREED wagon turns in and drives up one of the lanes. and LOUIS gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to a fresh grave on which the first flowers are starting to wilt. He sits down and takes a flower. He plu looking at the grave steadily. He says nothing for a long LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wrong. (Pause) What happened to you is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs toward THE CAMERA, happy and laughing, in SLOW MO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS is now weeping, but he seems calm just the same. PASCOW (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, doc. LOUIS looks at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW, bloody and mutilated, is standing by it. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barrier was not meant to be crossed. The ground is sour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is not put out of countenance in the slightest by PASC appearance; he probably knows PASCOW is just a figment of conscience or imagination, and so do we. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you where the ground is sour--the ground in my heart is sour. Let me tell you something else, Vic-baby: Wrong is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timmy Baterman. That was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk like an asshole even if you are just a bit of underdone potato or a blot of mustard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands mute, just looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS (weeping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was my son! He wasn't even two and he was run down in the fucking road and he was almost in pieces, and if you don't think I'm going to try...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIC has put on his boogie shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's crying harder. Abruptly he reaches out at the floral and knocks a bunch of them over. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it doesn't work--if he comes back like Timmy Baterman--I'll put him to sleep. But I'm going to try. (Pause) And if it doesn't work...they don't ever need to know.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPSTAIRS HALL NIGHT
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA MOVES LEISURELY along this hallway, which is l pictures of RACHEL, ELLIE...and GAGE (there may even be a in which LOUIS is featured, but damned few). Near the end hall a door is open and light spills out. RACHEL (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, you just had a bad dream. You know that, don't you? ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't a dream. It was Paxcow. THE CAMERA GOES THROUGH THE DOOR and into the room where staying. She's in bed, still badly upset. RACHEL is sitti bed beside her. There's a single lamp on the bedside tabl ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paxcow says Daddy's going to do something really bad. He-- RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this Paxcow? Is he like the boogeyman? ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a ghost. But he's a good ghost. RACHEL turns off the bed-lamp. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no ghosts, Ellie. I want you to go to sleep and forget all this nonsense. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you at least call and make sure daddy's okay? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I will. She kisses ELLIE. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now will you try to go to sleep? ELLIE (turns over on her side)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mom. RACHEL gets up and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW is here, halfway down the hall to the stairs, bloo ever. RACHEL doesn't see him. She looks perplexed, a woma to think of something. She stops very near him. RACHEL (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paxcow, why do I know that name? PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pascow. RACHEL suddenly straightens. She looks startled and afrai RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pascow? Was she saying Pascow? She suddenly heads for the stairs, fast.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CREED HOME IN LUDLOW NIGHT
dialogues.text: SOUND: A car starting up. The station wagon backs out and heads down the driveway. passes THE CAMERA, we see LOUIS driving. The wagon turns Route 9 and heads off. CAMERA HOLDS ON THE HOUSE. A beat of silence. Then: the t starts ringing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE GOLDMAN LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: IRWIN and DORY are watching RACHEL with some anxiety. RAC holding the phone to her ear. We can hear the FILTERED SO one ring after another. She hangs up. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not home. DORY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, he probably went out for a hamburger or a chicken dinner, dear. You know how men are when they're alone. Good old IRWIN'S face says that maybe LOUIS went out for of grams of coke and a whore in Nazi SS boots. RACHEL is dialing another number.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CRANDALL HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: SOUND: Phone starts to ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuffles to the telephone. His Walkman 'phones are aro neck. He's got a bottle of beer in one hand. JUD (picks up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello--you got Judson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Rachel Creed, Jud. I'm calling from Chicago. JUD (surprised voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicago! Is Louis with you? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...we're going to be here awhile, and he wanted a few days to wind up our affairs there. I just wondered if he was with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face says this is very serious. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--but if he drops by, I'll tell him to call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jud, do you remember the name of the student that died on Louis's first day at work? The one that was hit by a car? JUD (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't-- RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it Pascow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayuh, I think 'twas. If I see Louis come home before I go to bed, I'll tell him to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother. I'm coming home. JUD (alarmed voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel! RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jud. Goodbye. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Rachel! Don't do that! Rachel--! The buzz of an open line. Connection broken. JUD slowly r the receiver. The man looks very grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL comes down the stairs, dressed for travelling. She carrying a suitcase in one hand. Her parents meet her at of the stairs. DORY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel...darling...you're upset... a night's sleep... RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go. The connections are  tight, and I have to be at O'Hare in  forty minutes. Will you drive me, daddy? IRWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something's wrong, don't you? You know. And Ellie does, too. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. IRWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drive you. ELLIE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy? They all turn to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. Come and kiss me. ELLIE races into her arms.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LUDLOW CEMETERY NIGHT
dialogues.text: SOUND Of a car engine, THROBBING AND LOW. It cuts off. CAMERA MOVES IN on the low stone wall between the cemeter road. Beyond it we can see the roof of the CREED station LOUIS appears, dressed in dark clothes. He looks both way tosses a big duffle bag over the wall. Stuff clanks insid LOUIS climbs over the wall, grabs his bag, and checks out scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet city of the dead. Spooky. SOUND of crickets: Ree- ree...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads for GAGE'S grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come with you if you want, honey. RACHEL (shakes her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got three planes to catch and I got the last seats on two of them. It's like God saved them for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRWIN'S car heads for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS approaches it slowly and sets down his bag of grave equipment. He sets aside the remaining floral tributes an opens the bag and takes out the spade. He looks down at t for a long second. LOUIS (low)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna bust you out, son. He starts to shovel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Digging...throwing...digging again. Already the shape of excavation is beginning to show. The work is easy; this e new and fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks impatient, but RACHEL looks half crazy. PILOT (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Captain speaking. I'm sorry about this delay, folks, but we've got a real low ceiling tonight and air traffic control's playing it safe. Looks like it's going to be about half an hour before we get on a roll, so I'm turning off the NO SMOKING sign. SOUND: Bing! There's a general groan. CAMERA MOVES IN ON RACHEL, who h her eyes. I think she's praying.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GAGE'S GRAVE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Now it's pretty deep. Four feet, maybe. LOUIS is standing We see his feet as the shovel goes up and down, up and do

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LOUIS NIGHT
dialogues.text: He's sweating and dirt-streaked. He's tossing dirt on a b Suddenly, as he takes another shovelful, we hear a SCRAPI He tosses the shovel aside and squats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a white streak on the bottom of the grave--the to GAGE'S coffin. LOUIS swipes his hand through the loose di uncovering more, and then he begins to sweep off the top coffin with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD comes out. He's wearing a light jacket. His Walkman ' are around his neck. He's got a six-pack. He looks at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You done it, you stupid old man... now you got to undo it. He puts his earphones on. Cracks a beer. Lights a cigaret Pushes the PLAY button on the deck. Faint SOUNDS of The C buzz-sawing "Rock The Casbah." JUD begins to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs out of the grave and opens his duffle bag. He s pull out the pick. SOUND of an approaching car. LOUIS freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car comes cruising slowly along. The spotlight o driver's side comes on and runs along the graveyard's sto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching. Waiting. Hardly breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reaches the end of the wall. Everything looks jake. Th spotlight goes out and the police car speeds up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He relaxes perceptibly. He gets the pick and drops back i grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS inserts the tip of the pick in the flange of the co levers it. CRACKING SOUND. Again. More CRACKING. Again. A lock breaks. The coffin lid comes up a little, dirt gritt the hinges.

dialogues.text: Here's a man on the thinnest edge between sanity and madn

dialogues.text: SEATMATE

dialogues.text: Think you'll make your connection in Boston? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying on his stomach, reaching in. We hear the SOUND grating in hinges again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking up into his face. If GAGE had a POV, this w it. LOUIS'S face fills with a terrible grief. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Gage--oh, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His chin slips to his chest, even though we hear Creedenc 'phones and to him the sound must be at blastoff levels. long round ash on his cigarette in the tray. A couple of beer cans on the table beside him. A truck blasts by, startling him out of his doze. He jerk head up suddenly...and slaps himself. He's okay...for now

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sitting on the edge of the grave, holding his dead his arms, rocking him. GAGE is back to us. We see only a limp figure in a dark suit. Hair flops limply. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be all right...I swear it's going to be all right... The canvas tarp has been spread open to the right. LOUIS lay his son down on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the tarp over GAGE, making a roll. He then prod from the duffle bag. He cuts the rope and begins to tie o around one end of the canvas roll containing the corpse o son.

dialogues.text: PILOT (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening again, ladies and gentlemen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her seatmate is knitting something. Across the aisle sits PASCOW, bloody but serene, hands clasped in his lap, look straight ahead. RACHEL looks around tensely. PILOT (continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm delighted to tell you that we've got a strong tail-wind tonight and we expect to arrive at Boston's Logan Airport almost on time. PASCOW clenches his fist in a "That's one for our side!" RACHEL (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God. Her SEATMATE looks at her a bit strangely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got the bundle containing his son and the duffle-bag tools. He runs bent over. He reaches the wall and there's SOUND of another motor. He crouches at the base of the wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crouching against his side of the wall and sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stops. The COP gets out. He walks slowly toward the wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crouched. Now we see the COP looking over the top. If he down...but he doesn't. Instead he turns around so we see LOUIS looks up, miserably scared, pouring sweat. Silence. Then: SOUND of the cop taking a whiz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Relief. SOUND of his fly being zipped. He looks back cemetery for a moment. COP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't afraid of no ghost. He walks back to his cruiser, gets in, and hauls ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He collapses with relief. Then he gets up and looks cauti over the wall. Nothing there but his car, parked a little on the other side of the road. He tosses the duffle bag over the top of the wall. He put canvas roll containing GAGE on top of the wall. Then he v over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the roll, gets the duffle bag hooked over his sh the string, and runs across the road like a soldier cross territory. He goes to the rear of the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the body down. He feels in his pocket for his key keys. Mild consternation. He looks around, feeling expose other pocket. Still no keys. More consternation. He begin feverishly through his pockets. Maybe in his jacket? Nope SOUND: An approaching car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A civilian--not the ubiquitous cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his pockets out, spilling change everywhere. Not Suddenly a little light goes on in his eyes. He goes to t driver's side of the car and looks in at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The keys are in the switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snatches the keys and returns to the back of the wagon the key to open the doorgate. He puts GAGE'S body in gent the duffle bag. He closes the doorgate and returns to the the car. He opens the driver's door and freezes. LOUIS returns to the rear, gets his keys from the doorgat back to the front, gets in, and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are debarking into the gate area. Through them com RACHEL, running fast, pushing some people, excusing herse incoherently. PASCOW is walking near her. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just time. If you run. Without looking at PASCOW, RACHEL takes off her shoes and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that, babe. The GATE AGENT looks puzzled, as if she just had a though maybe a gas pain). She stops closing the door. RACHEL run the area. She sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is just starting to swing ponderously away from the je

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it come back! FEMALE GATE AGENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE JETWAY NIGHT
dialogues.text: RACHEL stands all alone at the end of it. AMPLIFIED SOUNDS OF JET ENGINES. RACHEL (screams)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It starts to swing back to pick her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW appears behind her and puts a hand on her shoulder PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fast asleep with the tinny sound of Graham Parker co of his Walkman 'phones. SOUND: An approaching car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station wagon turns in and parks. LOUIS gets out. He back, removes the body in the tarp and the duffle bag fil tools. He manages to get everything together and walks to of the path. He looks at:

dialogues.text: Off it goes, glimmering in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds the corpse of his little boy to him. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please God--let this work. He sets off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zonked out. He missed the whole thing. Nice going, Jud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis passes under like a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS is crying. He crosses to the deadfall. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't gonna stop, Gage. Ain't gonna look down. He begins to mount the deadfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches the top. And woven into the deadfall, behind h facing the Pet Sematary, is that snarling face. LOUIS descends the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS reaches the bottom and looks at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The path winds onward through those gigantic trees--it gl slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That phosphorescent glow is a lot more pronounced. SOUNDS CRICKETS and FROGS. The water is mucky and still. Hummock up like knobs on the back of a creature best not seen. Fo through the dead trees. LOUIS doesn't want to go in there man. I wouldn't either. But he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASCOW is lounging back against the rack of folders--and some of them bloody. HERTZ CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry...it's been very busy tonight. I really don't have anything. PASCOW

dialogues.text: What about the Aries K with the scratch on the side? The CLERK starts looking through her papers. CLERK

dialogues.text: I do have an Aries K, but it came in sort of beat up--there's a long scrape up one side-- RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes walking toward THE CAMERA with GAGE in his arms duffle bag over his shoulder. Mist swirls around him. The landscape is weird, surreal. CRICKET SOUNDS, AMPLIFIED. I there are a lot of swampy, marshy SOUNDS--too many. It so almost prehistoric.

dialogues.speaker: SOUND
dialogues.text: LOUIS stops. He looks slowly around at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A demonic face takes shape in the mist and FLOATS SLOWLY THE CAMERA. It runs out a tongue that's about nine feet l Its eyes blow out. Blood and thick, gooey stuff runs from sockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes his eyes. After a moment he opens them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? Just imagination. Just--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can barely see them because they are thick in mist, bu standing on a couple of low, marshy tussocks. Suddenly a tentacle slimes its way out of the standing water and sli around his ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing...there. He turns around and begins to walk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tentacle falls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MYRIAD SOUNDS, none of them pleasant--laughter, gobbling screams. Sounds like the swamp has been invaded by a pack escaped lunatics. LOUIS continues on regardless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS comes into the frame. He's obviously tiring now, bu keeps moving along. SOUND: Approaching footsteps. Big ones. Thudding ones. So is coming which sounds approximately the size of a Tyrann Rex. And it just keeps getting louder and louder and loud looks plenty scared. SOUND: A falling tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those SOUNDS keep getting closer and closer. Another tree we see this one. And now we see a SHAPE--just a SHAPE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's scared almost to death. His face turns up...up...up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is vaguely manlike: perhaps sixty feet tall, perhaps e don't see it very well, nor do we have to--I'm not even s flesh and blood. But there is a clear suggestion of a hea turns and looks down...looks at LOUIS CREED. We see great eyes the size of lighthouse lamps. It makes a huge GRUNTING SOUND...and then walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND OF FOOTFALLS is slowly diminishing. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the Wendigo. Dear God, I think the Wendigo just passed within sixty feet of me. Slowly he begins to walk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the extreme f.g. is a tree which has just fallen--it i small tree, either, but a great big old fir. LOUIS approaches it. Stops. Looks at the tree. Looks down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is a gigantic animal track--if it was full of water, could swim in it. It looks like no animal track we've eve before. Three big claws at the end of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks up again. His face is set and hard. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. Come on, Gage. He starts to walk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND: The wind, lonesome and keening. THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY toward the slope, dreaming its wa those rocky cairns...most of them burst apart. SOUND: Tortured breathing. Panting. LOUIS toils his way into view, carrying his bundle. He re top. He makes his way slowly into the burying ground. He over a rock. Falls down. Slowly gathers his things togeth gets up again. He goes a little further and then stops an at:

dialogues.text: We can also see the shredded remains of a green garbage b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slowly kneels down. He puts the canvas tarp to one sid slowly takes the pick and shovel from the duffle bag. By clearly a man approaching total exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It tracks past THE CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of them look tense. RACHEL is bolt upright behind th Suddenly, BANG! as one of the tires blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes skidding and slueing across the road, the rear ti off the rim. IT climbs the curb and hits a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lurches forward, but she's wearing her seat-belt--goo She unbuckles it and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at the car, which now has quite a bit more wron than just a scratch up the side. RACHEL slumps, near tears. LOUIS isn't the only one who's through a lot tonight. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what? PASCOW comes from around the tree as RACHEL walks to the looking for cars, or something. He looks urgent and upset PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's trying to stop you. Do you hear me? It's trying to stop you. RACHEL looks around uncertainly...a little afraid. As she the scene she looks at--and through--PASCOW. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anyone there? After a moment of silence she turns back to the road. Lig appear and brighten as a car approaches. RACHEL steps to shoulder and after a moment she sticks out her thumb, sur the first time in her life. The car sweeps by her without slowing.

dialogues.text: LOUIS'S hands enter the shot and put a few more rocks on CAMERA PULLS BACK and we see him surveying his work. Besi the canvas tarp, now open and empty. Absently, LOUIS stuffs the tarp into the duffle bag (wher tools have also been replaced) and stands up with a wince hand goes to his lower back. He looks down at the cairn. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back to me, Gage. Come back to us. He turns away toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's walking down the shoulder with her high heels in on Lights. An approaching car. She turns, thumb out. The car by. RACHEL (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: IN YOUR BEDROOM, ASSHOLE
dialogues.text: She starts walking again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS is moving down the path. As he passes the tire swin pushes it, setting it in motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS slings the duffle bag wearily to one side and goes kitchen. CHURCH is under the table but LOUIS Doesn't see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock on the bedtable reads 2:17 A.M. LOUIS falls fac on the immaculate bedspread and lies still. In this shot we should note the closet door is standing o

Rocks begin to tumble as GAGE starts to come out of his g

dialogues.text: Fast asleep on the coverlet in his dirty jeans and black

dialogues.text: THE CAMERA MOVES IN on that snarling face. SOUNDS: GAGE coming. Dead dry breath. Low snarling noises Now we see small feet in dirty black shoes walking down t deadfall.

dialogues.text: It sweeps past THE CAMERA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you go any faster? TRUCKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. If you only understood how important this is-- TRUCKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, babe. Only if we get stopped, next time I'll be the one hitchin' and you can give me a ride.

JUD straightens up so suddenly he almost falls off his ch hands go first to his earphones--his first thought on wak that it's coming from there--and then he hurries inside. CAMERA PANS DOWN to small muddy tracks on the porch floor

dialogues.text: It's dimly lit by light-spill from the living room and ki JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, stop playing games! SOUND: Molly Hatchet, "Flirtin' with Disaster," being pla end, from upstairs. JUD hurries up. Let me suggest that there is a certain ps at work here--for the moment he's more concerned about wa neighborhood with all this high-decible rock and roll tha the prowler...and he would certainly know who--or what--t prowler was, if he had time to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters and turns on the light. We see a portable phono with the record, turning. JUD rushes over and turns it of He looks around, and we see by his face that he knows. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage? (Pause) Are you the one playing games? He goes to the window and looks out at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns slowly and walks toward the bed. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage? Come on out. He reaches in his pocket and brings out a pocket-knife. H the blade. JUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to show you something. SOUND: Miaow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD (to the cat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you--?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small hand holding a scalpel shoots out from beneath th of the coverlet and slashes JUD'S calf,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He screams with pain and staggers backward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other hand shoots out. GAGE grabs one of JUD'S ankles pulls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a startled yell, he falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's gotta be pretty rough. George will know what t finally see GAGE, but it should be clear to us that it's really GAGE at all. Some daemonic presence is riding insi mouldering, disfigured shell of GAGE. There is a struggle. JUD is repeatedly slashed with the s Perhaps he gets GAGE a time or two with the pocketknife. GAGE screams and gibbers--nothing intelligible here; only JUD expires. GAGE sits on top of him...and then bites into his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headlights. RACHEL'S truck has arrived. It pulls up. RACHEL opens the passenger door, which is on JUD'S side.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAB
dialogues.text: We can see PASCOW sitting in the passenger seat where RAC was. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. TRUCKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get a ticket, so you're welcome, lady. (And, more seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever your problems are, I hope they work out. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the end of the line for me, too--I'm not allowed any further. RACHEL (to the trucker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure things will be fine. PASCOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. She closes the door and steps down. The truck starts off with a HISS OF RELEASED AIRBRAKES. A pulls past her, RACHEL starts across the road, when: GAGE (soft voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy! She stops, startled. Her face wears a "did I hear that?"  expression. She looks back toward JUD'S house. GAGE (soft voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy! RACHEL walks halfway up JUD'S paved walk and looks at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one place in the whole world we do not want RACHEL to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes. Up the steps to the porch. All through this she travelling with two bags: her handbag and a light tote wi initials on it. Now she sets the tote down on the top ste opens the porch door. She looks very uncertain. This is the wee hours of the mo and someone else's house. But...that voice... GAGE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy, I need you! RACHEL looks stunned--rocked. She steps onto the porch. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who-- The door to the house swings open. After a moment CHURCH into the doorway and sits down. CHURCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miaow! RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Church! GAGE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy, I need you! She crosses to the open door. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage? Gage? No answer. RACHEL steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's restless, having a very bad dream, from the look. He back and forth. Closer and closer to the edge. Finally, w wild yell, he goes over onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes awake. Sits up. Ouch! He's aches from top to bot side to side...but his back is worst. His hands go to it. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus! He starts to get up very slowly, and this his eyes fix on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the house, go to the closet, then leave again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage--? He scrambles for the closet, his aches and pains forgotte stares in wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls the doctor-bag out. His original hope is now tem with the first signs of fear. He begins to go through the bag. Suddenly he brings out a case and opens it. The case empty, but the indented shape is clear. There was a scalp this case...but not anymore. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. (Pause) Gage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage! LOUIS stands there, tensely listening, for a moment or tw there's only silence. He rushes down the hallway and open door to GAGE'S room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes downstairs, yelling GAGE'S name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. The phone RINGS. LOUIS almost jumps out of his s reaching for it. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello! IRWIN (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Louis--it's Irwin. I just wanted to be sure Rachel got back all right. As IRWIN says this, LOUIS'S eyes fix upon something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One set comes in from the shed-garage and heads for the p upstairs. The other comes out of the parlor and crosses t kitchen door giving directly on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his eyes we suddenly see that he understands everythin almost everything. IRWIN (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis...are you there? LOUIS (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--I'm here. IRWIN (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she get there all right? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she's fine. IRWIN (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, put her on at that end and I'll put Ellie on at this one. Ellie's very worried about her mother. (Pause) She's almost in hysterics. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She...Rachel's asleep. IRWIN (an edge in his voice now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I suggest you wake her up. Ellie...I think she had a dream that her mother was dead. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you right back. IRWIN (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis--! But LOUIS, whose last few responses have been almost tran hangs up. He looks at the tracks, then goes into the parl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiny bloody hands lift it off the cradle. A tiny bloody f dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone starts to ring. After two or three ringy-dingys looking extremely upset, comes out of the parlor and pick LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin, you'll just have to-- GAGE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm at Jud's, daddy. Will you come over and play with me? LOUIS is dumbfounded...slack-mouthed with terror. LOUIS (a bare whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage? GAGE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy already came. We played, daddy. First I played with Jud and then mommy came and I played with mommy. We had an awful good time. Now I want to play with you. GAGE begins to giggle...a really awful sound. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do? What did you-- CLICK! The GAGE-THING hangs up, still giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the doctor-bag down on the bed and roots through comes up with three syringes, still wrapped in paper, and them aside. Then he roots around some more and comes up w several ampoules. He holds one up for inspection and we c the word MORPHINE on it very clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carries the syringes and ampoules of morphine over to window. His hair has gone partially white. He fills all three syringes with morphine (using two ampo each syringe--i.e., enough to kill a polar bear) and puts the left breast pocket of his shirt. He puts the spare am the right breast pocket of his shirt. LOUIS is slowly going insane. What remains of his rationa like a rapidly fraying rope. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you buy is what you own, and sooner or later what you own comes home to you. Wasn't that what you said, Jud? Wasn't that pretty much it? He leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS comes out the door. In one hand he's got a raw pork the other he is carrying a pair of Playtex rubber gloves. to the soft shoulder and waits for an Orinco truck to pas he crosses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks most of the way to the house, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, humping his back warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Church. Want some grub? He tosses the pork chop onto the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries down the steps, goes to the chop, sniffs it, a to chow up. He looks up at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is pulling on the rubber gloves. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind me. Eat it while you can. Eat all you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts worrying the chop again. Smack-smack-smack.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS AND CHURCH
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat all you can...all you want... that's right...today's Thanksgiving day for cats, but only if they came back from the dead... He finishes with the gloves, gets one of the loaded syrin of his breast pocket, holds it up, squirts a drop out of then moves toward CHURCH. CHURCH looks up. LOUIS stops moving. CHURCH starts eating and LOUIS starts moving again as soon as he does. All the talks to the cat in that soothing voice. He bends down... him. CHURCH begins to squall and fight. LOUIS holds onto him. to get the syringe into the cat and CHURCH almost gets aw LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The syringe plunges into his haunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The needle is still dangling out of CHURCH'S haunch. The dazed. It tries to walk and falls over on its side. It tr get up...and then falls over again. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Lie down. Play dead. Be dead. He walks to the porch steps and picks up the tote-bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any doubt he might have allowed himself the luxury of hav erased by the initials--R.C., same as the cola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twang! One of the few remaining strands of sanity has now He looks back at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs the steps and goes onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strips off the rubber gloves. He tosses them onto the beside JUD'S beer-cans as he goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark in here, and spooky. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel? (Pause) Jud? (Longer pause) Gage? No answer. He looks down and sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of RACHEL'S shoes. It lies by the foot of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes over and picks up the shoe. It's a three-quarter it's pretty badly scuffed. RACHEL, after all, did some pr travelling to get here. There's a spot of blood on it. SOUND: A low giggle. LOUIS looks up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mighty dark. Mighty shadowy. SOUND: Another giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAGE (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's play, daddy! Let's play hide and go seek!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes one of the loaded syringes from his pocket. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Gage...let's. He begins to climb the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS arrives on the landing. We begin the nerve-wracking of checking rooms. First, the bathroom...and the shower c of course pulled. LOUIS yanks it back. Nothing. He checks the linen closet. Nothing. Goes back to the hal down it. He walks slowly along it. He checks one room. It guest room. Shadowy and empty. Down the hall. A closet door. A bag falls off the top she bunch of ceramics inside it SHATTER LOUDLY. LOUIS flinche Down the hall. Now he's at JUD'S room. He goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks the closet. No go. He steps around the bed and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bloodstain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets down on his hands and knees and examines the bloo He sees the skirt on the bedspread. He lifts it. He is no nose with JUD, who is dead with his eyes open, an express incredible horror on his face. The DOOR SLAMS. LOUIS bolts to his feet as GIGGLES fade down the hall. Slowly, he kneels down and speaks to the skirt of the spr which has mercifully fallen back into place. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Jud. I'm so sorry. I'm-- There's a SQUEAKING, SQUEALING SOUND. LOUIS turns around. He gets up again. He starts for the d he turns back and speaks to JUD again. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to set things back in order. I...I know just what to do. He goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes one of the two remaining loaded syringes from hi pocket. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gage? Another SQUEAKING SOUND. And another GIGGLE. LOUIS starts slowly forward. He gets about halfway down t and our nerves are tuned to the breaking point--when ther SQUEALING CREAK and a GRATING THUMP from overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This happens fast. The trap--which presumably gives on th with a set of folding stairs--rises, and RACHEL'S body pl down through and then hangs, swinging: she has been bound the armpits and as become a grotesque parody of MISSY DAN Half her face is gone. Eaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He SCREAMS and backs against the wall. Twang! The last si thread parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaps down, crashes on the floor, and then picks himse is waving the scalpel. GAGE (screeching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allee-allee-in-free! allee-allee- in-free! Allee-allee-in-free!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't choreograph all the moves, but GAGE slashes his s father up pretty badly with the scalpel. He's screeching time. LOUIS finally begins to react. He grapples with the critter, and tries to get the syringe into him. No good. batted out of his hand just before he can do it. It break LOUIS and GAGE fall to the floor. LOUIS gets the other sy of his pocket, but it's also knocked out of his hand. Onl consolation is this one isn't broken. It rolls off along floor. LOUIS finally manages to get it again as the strug on, and plunges it into GAGE'S neck. GAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fair! NO FAIR! He gets to his feet, clawing for the needle lolling out o neck. He's lost all interest in his father. He goes stagg away. He's slowing down. He goes to his knees...and falls face. LOUIS watches this... and then his vacant, half-catatonic goes to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She swings slowly back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has passed. It's late afternoon. LOUIS comes out wit sheet-wrapped form in his arms. RACHEL, of course. He sets the body down and goes back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's splashing around a can of coal-oil. When he's got th wetted down to his satisfaction, he goes to the door, lig match, and tosses it. Flame runs across the floor. The fire is slow at first, b it begins to gain rapidly. LOUIS goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the sheet-wrapped form of his wife and walks the side of the house as flames shoot through the kitchen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS appears with his shrouded burden and approaches the

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SMOULDERING RUINS OF THE CRANDALL HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: CAMERA HOLDS FOR A MOMENT, then rises and looks toward th house. There's one light on--in the kitchen. TOLLING CONTINUES: Three...four...five...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS is filthy, covered with dried blood. He is playing Patience. He holds a handful of cards. TOLLING CONTINUES: Six...seven... SOUND: The back door opens. SOUND: Crickets from outside. Ree-ree-ree... SOUND: Gritting footsteps. LOUIS looks up. He doesn't look behind, at what's coming. straight ahead. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what you own always comes home to you. He flips up one card. TOLLING CONTINUES: Eight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Bitch, the Queen of Spades, she who supposedly p the laddies in the Tower. LOUIS'S hand falls upon it. TOLLING CONTINUES: Nine...ten...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand clotted with grave-dirt falls on his shoulder. A w hand. TOLLING CONCLUDES: Eleven...twelve... RACHEL (voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling. FADE OUT ON THE SOUND OF CRICKETS.
